dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paolo, the first of 8 fedayeen, dressed as athletes in tr suits, carrying duffel bags, are climbing over the wire fence. A group of American athletes, happy and drunk, comes ambl down the sidewalk towards the Palestinians,laughing, tryi to be quiet. The Palestinians freeze, looking at one anot alarmed; one of their number is halfway over the fence. T starts to unzip his duffel bag, ready to go for his gun. Issa stops him, saying something softly in Arabic. The Americans gather around the Palestinians.

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN ATHLETE, (CASTING TBD)
dialogues.text: Aw shame shame ! Closin’ down the biergarten! Hundred meter dash powered by knockwurst and lager! Issa smiles at him, shrugs to indicate he doesn’t underst

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN ATHLETE, (CASTING TBD)
dialogues.text: Where you guys from? What’s your event?

dialogues.speaker: AMERICAN ATHLETE, (CASTING TBD)
dialogues.text: He doesn’t speak English, man. Let's help ‘em over. The athlete squats, cups his hands, indicates that he'll Issa a boost over the fence. Issa indicates to one of his men to take the offer. The Americans cheerfully help the Palestinians climb over the fence, handing them their duf bags. Over the fence, the Americans and Palestinians shake hand and the Americans walk off toward their building. The Palestinians are surprised and amused, and also very nerv

dialogues.speaker: VILLAGE, MUNICH
dialogues.text: The fedayeen are taking off their tracks suits, revealing ordinary clothes underneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Palestinians walk as a group through the sleeping Village, down an avenue of modern apartment buildings. Th arrive at 31 Connollystrasse and stop. They enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING, 4AM, (STAGE/ICE RINK)
dialogues.text: The Palestinians are silently removing their rifles from their duffel bags. One by one we see them put stocking masks over their head They all look..scared; some are eager, some just scared. look at each other once the masks are on, giving each oth courage. A close-up on Issa’s face, serious and intelligent; his e Issa motions to the others to be ready. He slowly inserts passkey into the lock of the door of the apartment. He tu the key as guietly as he can. Very gently and slowly he begins to open the door.

dialogues.speaker: EARLY MORNING, 4AM, (STAGE ICE/RINK)
dialogues.text: On the other side of the door, Yossef Gutfreund, a wrestl referee, sees that the door is being opened by a man wear amask. He sees the glint of light on a machine gun barrel He shouts to wake up the others. Then he hurls himself against the door. Someone on the other side manages to sh the barrel of an AK-47 in the way before the door can clo Guttfreund is struggling mightily against eight men to ho the door closed Behind him, Tuvia Sokolovsky leaps up, breaks the glass i window and starts to crawl out. Down the hall in another bedroom, Moshe Weinberg, the wrestling coach, half-asleep in shorts and a t-shirt, is scrambling out of bed. He turns into the apartment to scream out a warning to t other athletes

dialogues.speaker: ISRAELI BROADCASTING AUTHORITY'S SPECIAL MUNICH COVERAG
dialogues.text: Black-and-white, the Israeli anchor sitting at a strange angle in front of an aerial shot of the Olympic Stadium:

dialogues.speaker: ISRAELI NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Good morning from Munich. 36 Years have passed since Jewish blood was spilled. The blood of 6 million. This morning Germany absorbed the blood of one or two of the Israeli delegation to the Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Zvi Zamir is struggling out of his pajamas while watching television. His wife is in her bathrobe, crying. Several IDF officers are standing behind them, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: ISRAELI NEWS ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There is great uncertainty about how many Israelis are being held hostage in the apartment at 31 Connollystrasse in the Olympic Village. Moshe Weinberg, the weight-lifting coach, was reportedly shot twice in the head, once in the stomach, and then dragged outside, where he died. curT TO TV

dialogues.speaker: BBC WORLD NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: ~- and it now appears that this group, calling itself Black September, has tossed a piece of Paper out the window of the apartment, a list of demands -- cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oA (NOTE: ISSA‘S FACE IS BLACKENED WITH SHOEPOLISH IN THIS S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bar has opened its doors and a television set is prop up on a table. A large crowd of Israelis, men, women, schoolkids, secular and religious people, a few Arab- Israelis, have gathered around.

dialogues.speaker: BBC WORLD NEWS REPORTER
dialogues.text: They want what they call “the Israeli war machine” to release 200 Arabs in Israeli prisons which it insists are political prisoners, held without trial, or the hostages will be killed. The terrorist communique ends with an appeal for “revolutionaries of the world to unite.” INT. IN GOLDA MEIR’S HOUSE -~ EARLY MORNING : 8A Golda in the dark, in silhouette, recognizable only by he profile and the frizzy hair, in a housecoat, cup of coffe and cigarette, watching. A German reporter, whe can be seen standing near the BBC reporter.

dialogues.speaker: IN ARABIC
dialogues.text: The deadline for the release of the Palestinian prisoners is only two and a half hours from now. The governor of the state of Bavaria and the FDR Minister of the Interior are working to arrange a meeting with Issa, the head of the Black September group --

dialogues.speaker: OMIT 9
dialogues.text: OMITTED oA

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON, (NEP STADIUM)
dialogues.text: Olympic athletes from around the world are watching the German Minister of the Interior doing a press conference. Camera crews and individual photographers are filming the watching TV. Journalists from the USA, Spain and Italy ar interviewing athletes from USSR (2), USA, Mexico, Japan, Sweden and Kenya. There's a murmur of translation into ma languages.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER OF THE INTERIOR, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: The peace of the Olympics games has been shattered by a murderous band of criminal terrorists. The whole world views this deplorable deed with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: — AFTERNOON (STAGE .ICE/RINK). o All nine athletes are sitting on the floor, bound at the wrists and feet and to one another in groups of 3. The fedayeen stand around, holding onto their AK47s. Two of the fedayeen have been hurt: Salah(aka Afif Ahmed Hamid) has a bloody bandage wrapped around his head-- the a knife wound in his forehead. The left side of Badran’s face is a swollen gory mess, a punch having cut him and knocked out teeth. The television is on. Everyone’s watching Paolo pull a stocking mask over his head, pick up his gun and step out the room onto the balcony. They watch him through the window, leaning over the balco railing. His image simultaneously appears on TV. One of t fedayeen, Tony, notices the TV, nudges Abu-Halah, who loo at the TV. Then Tony turns to one of the athletes:

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Everyone's watching. Everyone in the world. The athletes also turn from watching out the balcony to watching the image on TV. (PLAYBACK ~~ STOCK FOOTAGE)

dialogues.speaker: BETHLEHEM
dialogues.text: A large group of Palestinian woman are crowded in front o television. There's no sound. cuT TO TV SCREEN: LiA In silence, the famous footage of the man ~~ Paolo ~~ on balcony, bending to look down and around, wearing the stocking mask.

dialogues.speaker: 11B
dialogues.text: i1lBB The women, watching, are discussing in murmurs what they On their TV, the same footage of Paulo on the balcony. So of the women are shaking their heads in disbelief, some a smiling. CUT BACK To TV SCREEN: 11B The footage of Paulo again. He looks over the balcony and then he goes inside. Over this, Jim McKay's voice, with Spanish and Arabic subtitling.

dialogues.speaker: JIM MCKAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: See the man with the stocking mask... weird... does it mean “all right” or “it‘s all over... come and get us?”

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON, (STAGE/ICE RINK)
dialogues.text: All nine athletes and Issa, Tony, Abu Hallah, Kader, Badr and Salah are watching television: cur TO TV: Paolo leaves the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: JIM MCKAY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (with German subtitling: } This is live, this is happening now...

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: 1iBBB lic In the room: While everyone’s watching Paolo on TV step o the balcony, the actual Paolo steps off the balcony and b into the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the stadium, hordes of Olympic officials and groundskeepers in blue blazers and uniforms are running about, conferring with clipboards, wielding brooms and maintenance equipment, tidying, working to get the games restarted, their behavior and demeanor bizarrely bright a energetic. The staff in the media HQ is watching this going on, quie discussing the action on the field, while behind them, on TV monitors, footage of crowds assembled outside the Olym village, protesting the games going on during the crisis. over this a BBC reporter is talking:

dialogues.speaker: BBC WORLD NEWS REPORTER, (V.C.)
dialogues.text: Prime Minister Golda Meir, holding fast to her government’s policy of refusing to negotiate with the terrorists,says that no Israelis anywhere on earth will be safe if she gives in. Though one suspects there must be tremendous pressure to do so from the families of the captive men who -~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Munich police are suiting up for the raid, putting on bulky kevlar vests and then track suits on top of them, checking ammo and assault rifles, putting these in sports bags, and watching the coverage all the while. cur TO TV

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: Footage of crowds at the Olympics stadium, track and fiel events going on.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN BROADCASTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: -- we're confirming now the International Olympic Committee's decision not te cancel the competition, to allow the Games to continue, only a few hundred yards from where this deadly standoff is taking place, now that the noon deadline has been shifted to 5PM and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window of the media building, a crew is tryin focus a camera with a zoom lens on police activity across street. Two producers are watching one of the several TV monitors: cur TO TV

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: ABC News desk, Jim McKay: JIM MCKAY. . And can you tell us what you’re seeing now, Peter? The picture switches to footage of the Munich police dres in a weird amalgam of athletic clothing, storm-trooper helmets, guns in gym bags, running about, scaling the roo

dialogues.speaker: PETER JENNINGS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes Jim, it’s, well, that man is earrying a bag which obviously holds a large gun, and... These are Munich police officers who are preparing to wage an assault on the building as the 5PM deadline approaches, it's now 4:46 Jim and --

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The room's a mess, food and cigarettes and a barricaded d AK-47s are propped on furniture. Several young Palestinia men are watching TV, discussing what they’re seeing: On the screen, the police are filmed crouching/running ac the roof, and scaling the first and second floor balconie  Al3A The Palestinians in the apartment are arguing quietly, urgently about what to do, pointing at the tiny figures o the screen, getting their guns ready for battle.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: It's going to happen, they're coming in.

dialogues.speaker: SALAH
dialogues.text: We warned them, we said what would happen if there's any attempt, so maybe we have to do it.

dialogues.speaker: ABU-HALAH
dialogues.text: It’s just a show, it's just a fucking display, to show that they're tough, they won't risk it, don’t panic.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Go talk to them, go tell them to get back or something bad will happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This assault on the building certainly seems rather disorganized and dangerous, and, and is apparently being televised, and one wonders if the Palestinians and their hostages inside are watching. Issa, the leader, his face blackened with shoe polish, le the room.

dialogues.speaker: LATE AFTERNOON, (STAGE/ICE RINK)
dialogues.text: Issa pauses for a moment, collecting himself, then walks the hallway towards the exit, angry, unafraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same room as in scene 11C. The police are returning f the now-cancelled raid. They enter and throw down their weapons and gear on a table, furious, humiliated, disgust The television is playing: cur TO TV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Issa is standing with the German officials, engaged in discussion.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN REPORTER
dialogues.text: ~- when the leader of the fedayeen came out of the building and demanded that they call off the siege, pointing out that the entire operation was being watched on the television set within the apartment. CUT BACK TO; In the security room, the policemen have gathered, watchi the TV, muttering, still very angry, disgusted at having called off.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN REPORTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Apparently new demands have been made to move the fedayeen and their hostages, though it isn’t yet known where or when this might occur...

dialogues.speaker: EVENING, (NEP STADIUM)
dialogues.text: A lone 16MM video camera, a crew of two people and a sing flash photographer are filming and snapping shots of the scene unfolding at the far end of the garage: A green bus is waiting, idling. The nine athletes, blindfolded and bound to one another, facing out encircli their captors, are walking carefully to the door of the b This event is partly obscured from the camera by a crowd police and government officials who are standing in betwe their distant perch and the events unfolding by the bus. No one is speaking. The echoing garage is scarily quiet. The hostages and all eight fedayeen are on the bus. The b begins to rolls towards the exit. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: 13BB
dialogues.text: be be

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. THE MEDIA HO
dialogues.text: Inside the media HQ, a bank of television monitors, each an on- or off-camera reporter speaking in a different language. The monitors are showing the bus leaving the garage and heading down Connollystrasse. The night footag every monitor is grainy, chaotic and obscure.

dialogues.speaker: ENGLISH REPORTER
dialogues.text: They're moving slowly towards the bus, obvicusly wary of an assault from the German police who are standing at a distance, as instructed...

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH REPORTER
dialogues.text: The fedayeen are still heavily armed, the Israeli athletes bound and blindfolded and they seem dazed and uncertain. No one is clear about where they’re being taken but it‘s assumed to be an airport nearby.

dialogues.speaker: ISRAELI REPORTER
dialogues.text: As the long day has worn on, with deadlines approaching and passing unmarked, no further hostages having been killed since the bloody toll this morning, it's uncertain where things stand or what the abductors think they have to gain, other than their own safety.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN REPORTER
dialogues.text: This is our first glimpse of the hostages since this morning, it’s hard to see anything in the dim light of the garage and -- The terrorists are hiding within the circle of their captives, using them as shields...

dialogues.speaker: SPANISH REPORTER
dialogues.text: We're being kept at a distance by the authorities who have promised the terrorists a safe and quick getaway out of the garage and away from this building that’s now become famous the world over...

dialogues.speaker: ARAB REPORTER
dialogues.text: If rumors are correct, the bus will take the fedayeen and their prisoners to an airport for transportation to either Libya or Syria. This is a moment of great danger for everyone involved. cuUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: STADIUM
dialogues.text: The same group of reporters from the monitors in the prev scene, arrayed in front of TV cameras with long lenses, a number of still photographers as well, filming and photographing the bus leaving the garage. Policemen and soldiers in riot gear, are holding them at a distance fro the garage.  14

dialogues.speaker: 14A
dialogues.text: As the bus leaves the garage, some of the journalists who have been talking to the camera stop talking and turn to watch the bus drive down the street.

dialogues.speaker: KO TELEVISION SCREEN
dialogues.text: The bus driving up Connollystrasse and out of the compoun Again, the video footage is incomprehensible night filmin blur of lights and fragments of crowds, cars, buildings. single Israeli reporter is heard.

dialogues.speaker: ISRAELI REPORTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: No one seems to know if only the Arab gunmen will be taken in the helicopters, and no one knows of any airplane waiting at an airport to take the Arabs away. The West German agencies. seem to. be, at;.cross purposes, even working against one another. That’s all that’s known now, nothing is known. Someone’s hand switches the channel on the television set The camera pulls back to reveal: General Eytan Nadav and General Aharon Yariv, watching television. Yariv is on the phone, nodding, responding occasionally. Both men keep their eyes on the TV througho Behind them are many subalterns, high-ranking officers an civilians, watching the television and talking on the pho and to one another, strategizing. Nadav whispers something emphatic into Yariv'’s other ear nods while continuing his conversation on the phone and T watching. The strange, confusing night footage continues in silence a bit. Eventually out of the confusion, two helicopters are discernible, flying from the Village.  15 16 13.

dialogues.speaker: BBC REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The decision’s been made, what I’m hearing from here is that they are headed to an airport, called, um... Furstenfeldbruck, where a DC9 plane will be waiting to take the terrorists and their hostages to Libya or --

dialogues.speaker: AIRFIELD
dialogues.text: A small television is playing as the guards, not watching stare out the window -- the armored vehicles on televisio are roaring past the guard booth. ON TV: night-time chaos again. Mostly we see bright light piercing blackness, streaking the screen. Crowds, cars, soldiers, police, press. A German reporter is being shove aside as enter the gates.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN REPORTER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There are armored cars now, they -- They were stuck in traffic and now, an hour after we first heard gunfire and -- The sound of a big explosion. The TV camera lurches up to show a huge fireball, rising behind the perimeter fence f the direction of the runway and silhouetting the air traf tower. The guards in the guard booth rush out of the booth to se the fireball rising. (PLAYBACK ~- LIVE FEED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young woman, the wife of one of the athletes, is sittin a chair, clutching a framed picture of her husband. Behin her, a few friends and family are sitting. A teenaged gir is leaning against her chair, looking exhausted and frightened.

dialogues.speaker: ON TV
dialogues.text: israeli Broadcast Authority Munich coverage, the stadium backdrop, as before:  14.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ISRAELI NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: We have reports now that all the hostages, all nine hostages are safe. The wife of the athlete is rocking, slightly, trying to h jit in. She isn’t sobbing but tears are streaming down he face.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ISRAELI NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: We repeat, we have confirmed, it’s just past one AM, the fighting ceased at midnight, that all the hostages are safe, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men and women and children are watching the Israeli broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER ISRAELI NEWS ANCHOR, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: All the hostages, we are told all the hostages are safe. And all the Arabs have been killed. Some of the men and women begin to weep. A ululating cry rises from the women; it becomes a great piercing cry of mourning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers in the IDF are watching a small television set.

dialogues.speaker: ISRAELI NEWS ANCHOR
dialogues.text: It has been learned that three of the nine Arab terrorists have survived the gun and grenade battle at Furstenfeldbruck Airport and are now in German custody. i8A OMITTED 18A i8-19A OMITTED 139-19A  20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later the same day. A modest, underfurnished modern israe apartment. Avner is sitting alone on a small sofa watchin television, a grim, tight expression on his face. His lar friendly dog, Charlie, is whining and nosing about for attention. Avner gently pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: Grainy footage of the flag-draped coffins of the murdered athletes being unloaded at Lod Airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bodies of the eleven murdered Olympic athletes arrived this morning at Lod Airport. The camera switches to show huge crowds gathered at night downtown Tel Aviv.

dialogues.speaker: ANCHOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Enormous crowds have gathered on Dizengoff Street, and in Jerusalem on the plaza in front of the Knesset. People are weeping, tearing their clothes... The funerals, which will be held tomorrow in Jerusalem, are expected to draw tens of thousands of mourners.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TC
dialogues.text: Avner, watching, is clenching his right fist so tight his tremors, then hyperflexing, again to the point of tremors With a sigh, Charlie settles nearby. Daphna, Avner's seven~months-pregnant wife, opens the fro docr, carrying the mail. Avner looks up at her and then b to the TV. They don’t say anything. He moves over to one end of the sofa, making room for her; she squeezes in bet him and the arm rest. They watch in silence.  23 24 25 26 16.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ISRAELI TELEVISION ANCHOR
dialogues.text: These are the names of members of the Israeli team at the Munich Olympics who were held hostage, beaten, and finally murdered by Arab terrorists. David Marc Berger. As she says each name, the face of the athlete appears on screen. Avner repeats each name quietly, or noiselessly, after the announcer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand places a grainy photo of an Arab man on a tabletop

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Dr. Wadi Haddad. INT. AVNER‘S APARTMENT, TEL AVIV - EARLY EVENING 23 On the television, a shot of the flags at the Olympics village being lowered to half mast. .

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ISRAELI TELEVISION ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Zeev Friedman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another photo of another Arab man.

dialogues.speaker: AR MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Abu Daoud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner and Daphna watching.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ISRAELI TELEVISION ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Yossef Gutfreund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another phote.

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Mahmoud Hamshari.  27 28 29 30 31 Another hand picks up the photo, passing it to yet anothe hand. INT. AVNER’S APARTMENT, TEL AVIV - EARLY EVENING 27 On the television, film footage of Paulo, standing on the balcony at 31 Connollystrasse, wearing his stocking mask, holding a gun.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ISRAELI TELEVISION ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Eliezer Halfin. Yosef Romano.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another photo.

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Wael Zwaiter. INT. AVNER‘S APARTMENT, TEL AVIV-- EARLY EVENING 29 Avner and Daphna watching.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ISRAELI TELEVISION ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Amitzur Shapira.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: (softly: ) Oh God. I think I knew his cousin,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another photo.

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Dr. Basil al-Kubaisi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A procession of coffins, draped with Israeli flags, are making their way through a massive, somber crowd. People weeping. A band is playing the Hatikvah.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ISRAELI TELEVISION ANCHOR
dialogues.text: Kehat Shorr. Mark Slavin. Andrei Spitzer.  32 33 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another photo.

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Kamal Nasser. Another phote.

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Kamal Adwan.

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Mahmoud Yussuf Najjer, also known as "Abu Yussuf". Another photo is placed as the previous photo is picked u

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Mohammed Boudia. Another photo. Then another.

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Hussein al-Chir. Ali Hassan Salameh. INT. AVNER’S APARTMENT, TEL AVIV - EARLY EVENING 33 Avner and Daphna, listening. Avner is still silently pronouncing the names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yacov Springer. Moshe Weinberg. Charlie is whining from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: DAHPNA
dialogues.text: I tried not to think about you but I couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I have the world’s most boring job. What‘s going to happen to me?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: They were just athletes. They went to the Olympics. Look what happened to them. What now?  34 19. Avner smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Now? Now we're going to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tabletop, pictures of the Arab men in a disorderly pi

dialogues.speaker: A MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Eleven names. The room is cluttered, shuttered, smoky, an air of siege crisis, and all its occupants are dishevelled, weary -- they ‘ve been arguing, fighting, planning, arguing again many many hours and it shows. Meir is rumpled, all busine hair a mess, wearing glasses. Around the table ten people are seated: Golda Meir, Gener Zvi Zamir, General Aharon Yariv, General Eytan Nadav, Mik Harari, head of Mossad’s Central Operational Group -- the voice announcing the names of the Palestinians --~ and fo other ministers, including Meir Shamgar, the Attorney General. Harari gathers together the photographs, and put them in a folder. He passes the folder te the Attorney General, who has before him another folder, thick with documents.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE HARARI
dialogues.text: Give us the order and we begin. Everyone at the table looks to Meir.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: It‘s the same as Eichmann. We say to these butchers, “You didn’t want te share this world with us, then we don’t have to share this world with you.” (to the Attorney General:) There’s legitimacy for this. The Attorney General winces.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Ambushed and slaughtered again. While the rest of the world is playing games, Glympic torches and brass bands and dead Jews in Germany. And the world couldn‘t care less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've responded. We sent seventy fighter jets.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER MINISTER
dialogues.text: A response no one heard.

dialogues.speaker: A MINISTER
dialogues.text: Air strikes on guerilla training centers. That’s a response.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL EYTAN NADAV
dialogues.text: No one notices what happens in the border camps.

dialogues.speaker: A MINISTER
dialogues.text: Sixty Arabs dead, at least, who knows how many wounded?

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL NADAV
dialogues.text: This is about fixing the world’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: ~ 4 “Well: itis.not just a. publicity. stunt. He holds up the photograph of Salameh for all to see.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: Let me remind you: Ali Hassan Salameh. He invented Black September. Brief silence in the room

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: These people... They’re sworn to destroy us. Forget peace for now. We have to show them we're strong. {a beat) We have laws, we represent civilization. Some people say we can’t afford to be civilized. I've always resisted such people. She looks sharply at Harari, he looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Angry:} But I don't know who these maniacs are or where they come from. Palestinians? Who are Palestinians? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are no such people. They're not... recognizable. You tell me, what law protects people like these? Today I'm hearing with new ears. A nod to Harari.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values. I have made a decision, The responsibility is entirely mine. The Attorney General opens the document folder. He takes photo, matches it with a document, and signs. He takes another photo, another document, and signs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner comes out of his apartment building. A government s is waiting for him. A soldier is standing beside the car, holding open the curbside passenger door. Avner's surpris

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Usually I take the bus.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: We're going to Jerusalem. Get in. Avner peers inside the car. ‘There's a soldier in the driver's seat. General Zamir is in the backseat. Avner leoks back at his front door, then gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner climbs into the car. He salutes the general, awkwar Zamir nods. The car pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You swore us in, my unit, when I joined Mossad. General Zamir nods.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: I don't remember you. Of course I know your father. General Zamir picks up the Jerusalem Post and, ignoring Avner, reads. Avner stares out the window. The car drives on.  37 22. INT. GOLDA MEIR‘S APARTMENT IN JERUSALEM - DAY 37 Avner and General Zamir enter the room. Seated on a couch and comfy chairs in an ordinary apartme paintings and photos on the wall: Golda Meir, Mike Harari General Aharon Yariv, General Eytan Nadav and Ephraim. Golda Meir looks calmer, resigned, more pulled-together t before. She’s dressed to look official.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Avner. It's been...

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Two years since --

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Sit. This is Harari. Avner nods, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: General Nadav over there, and this is General Yariv. How are you? How is your father?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: He's... um, fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Coffee? Wonderful to see you again. Avner shakes his head no, then yes. He looks at Ephraim, smiles at him but whom no one has introduced.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: {To Avner:) Sit. Avner sits, as does Zamir. Golda Meir serves him coffee.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: The chief of Mossad, two generals and the Prime Minister. Obviously it's important.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL YARIV
dialogues.text: This is something new. What happened in Munich changes everything. The rules, everything.  Silence. 23.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: We want to ask you, will you undertake a mission? An important mission. You will have to leave the country and your family. Maybe for years.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL YARIV
dialogues.text: And it's dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: You can't talk about it to anyone, not even your wife.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL YARIV
dialogues.text: You could die doing this, away from home, and no one will know where you're buried.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL NADAV
dialogues.text: (to Avner:) Now you should say something.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: Do you have any questions?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: So... this isn’t about guarding tourists on El Al jets? Zamir chuckles at this.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL NADAV
dialogues.text: No questions? Did we mention how dangerous it is?

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: You know my sister died Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: No, I +

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Cancer. I couldn't go to the athletes’ funerals because she died. That upset people, but... She was my sister. Family matters. Your wife is pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Yes, seven months.  24.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Mazeltov. Meir and Yariv exchange a look. Avner watches them.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA METR
dialogues.text: You were one of my favorite bodyguards, you know? I like neat, durable men.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You liked having the son of a hero around.

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Truth to be told, you don't look much like your father.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: GOLDA MEIR
dialogues.text: Your mother is who you resemble. She stands, and everyone stands. She pats Avner's cheek. After briefly conferring with Yariv, Meir leaves the room

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: (to Avner: ) What's your answer?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE HARARI
dialogues.text: Eleven unarmed Jewish boys, butchered. That's Jewish history. It's a heavy burden. Harari taps Avner‘s sternum, hard, with a blunt forefinge

dialogues.speaker: MIKE HARARI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish they’d asked me to do this. I wish I was younger. Harari cocks an ever-so-slightly skeptical eyebrow at Yar Avner sees it.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL NADAV
dialogues.text: If we don’t respond, if they think we're weak, there will be Munich every year. That’s it, you see. Irrefutable. A new Munich, every year. On and on. We can’t be weak. Nadav, Yariv, Zamir and Harari stand, ready to go.  38 42 25.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL ZAMIR
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning. If you can't decide in one day you can't decide. Ephraim watches Avner watch the generals and Harari leave

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Her sister died, but I think she didn't go to the athletes’ funerais because some people are angry at her for not negotiating with the terrorists. She didn't go to the funerals because she didn't want to be booed. It's a good sign that you didn't ask questions. You'll say yes. I'm your case officer. My name is Ephraim. Ephraim leaves. Avner is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner and Daphna are making love. She’s on top. They’re careful because she‘s so pregnant. They finish. Daphna lies down.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: How late in a pregnancy before you have to stop having sex?

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: Labor? Avner laughs. Silence. she looks

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. You won't be around. They lie still, not looking at one another. Then at Avner.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you? (not a joke:) Whatever they want, make sure they give you a raise. I need things. For the baby.  3g

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I can’t live with refusing this. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DAPENA
dialogues.text: Your mother, she knew what she was doing, she abandoned you at that kibbutz ~-

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: She didn't abandon me, my father had disappeared, he was in prison, she was overwhelmed, she -—~

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: So she put you in the kibbutz and abandoned you. And now you think Israel's your mother. So listen, Avner, I'm going to go along with this. Until I don't. You understand me?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I leve you.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: I'm not the hero’s nice wife. He grabs her. She resists. Then they hug, ferociously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ephraim is seated behind a desk in an entirely nondescrip room. Avner is seated across the desk. Ephraim takes a sh of paper from a desk drawer, slides it across the desk to Avner.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: First you resign from Mossad. Avner looks at Ephraim, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your new contract. It says we do not employ you, offer you benefits or pension or legal aid or medical assistance. It's a contract that there is no contract. Avner signs.  40

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Do I get a copy?

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: You don't. Your pension contribution refund. Ephraim hands Avner a check and puts the signed contracts back in the desk draw, locks it. Ephraim stands.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are now officially unofficial. Unemployed and uninsured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An accountant’s office adjacent to Room 27-5-H. Avner and Ephraim are standing. Behind a small, neat desk with an ; adding machine, an leathery-tough old man has interrupted work to talk to them,

dialogues.speaker: MOSSAD ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: You'll open two accounts at the Union de Banques Suisses in Geneva on Rue de la Commerce. Operational funds in one box, in the other, your salary. Which you don’t take till the mission ends, when you get what accumulates. Also for each of your men you open an account for his salary.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: How many men do I --

dialogues.speaker: MOSSAD ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: In the operational funds box we will deposit two hundred and fifty thousand American dollars. You take it out, we put more in. I want receipts. You're not working for Baron Rothschild, you're working for Israel, a small country. I'm an old Galicianer from a mud hut in the Ukraine and I don't trust Yekke putzes let loose in Europe with unlimited operational expenses.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I'm was born in Israel, I’m not a Yekke.  41 28.

dialogues.speaker: MOSSAD ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: Where’s your grampa from?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Frankfurt.

dialogues.speaker: MOSSAD ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: You‘’re a Yekke. tT want receipts. Take a train or a subway, no one needs taxis and airplanes all the time. Your wife receives monthly a thousand dollars in her bank account.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Also we'll leave messages in the box with the operational funds. And you can leave messages for us. But there shouldn't be messages.

dialogues.speaker: MOSSAD ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: I don't care about that. Bring me receipts. You got me?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I got you.

dialogues.speaker: MOSSAD ACCOUNTANT
dialogues.text: Whatever you're doing, somebody else is paying for it. Remember. The accountant dismisses them with a wave of his hand and returns to his calculations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ephraim and Avner are eating baklava from a white cardboa box.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: We have eleven Palestinian names. Each had a hand in planning Munich. You're going to kill them. Eleven men, one by one. They're all in Europe now. You'll stay there as long as it takes. Europe only, not the Arab countries, that’s for us, not you, and not the Eastern bloc, don’t upset the Russians, who needs it. You will have no contact with us.  29.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You're not going to give me any information?

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: We deposit money from a fund that doesn’t exist into a box we don’t know about in 4 bank we never set foot in. We can’t help you because we never heard of you before. You'll do what the terrorists do. You think they report back to home base? They don't. We want them dead. They walk a bit. Ephraim finishes a piece of baklava, smacking his lips, breathing the air.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing better than eating something sweet by the sea. You can ask questions now.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Am I-alone? «.. z

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Four others. They know useful things like cars, documents, clean- up to make sure you didn’t accidentally drop your fake passport next to the dead body. You're the team leader.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Who, um, who kills the targets?

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: You do. Who else? Use guns if you have to, but bombs are preferable. One of your guys knows how to make them. We want everyone to read in Le Monde some famous Arab terrorist is dead, who knows who blew him up?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: What‘s wrong with you?  30.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I’m not an experienced field operative. (getting it:) So I'm not known.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: And not even I know you now.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: And also I lived in Frankfurt when I was a kid, a Yekke Jew who knows his way around Europe --

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: That’s a good reason and here's one more: You're ordinary, you aren‘t a Sabra Charles Bronson.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I’m a Sabra.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Yeah I know. I know so much about you. .A nice sabra with a dog and a baby on the way and you won't shoot Spanish bellhops. No bellhops, no civilians. That kind of trouble we can't afford. The hard thing won’t be finding them. Some of them, anyway, aren‘t so carefully hidden. The hard thing will be not punishing yourselves by getting caught or getting killed.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Are there other teams? Or --

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: You're underprepared. What else is new? Were we prepared to build our owh country? We did it anyway. You'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: How come you’re so sure?

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Because every Jew on earth saw those eleven coffins and thought "I want to kill the ones who did this." You got lucky. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 a4 45 Bi. EPHRAIM {cont'‘d) You want to say this was a mistake? Want to pass this job on to someone else? Now's the time. No one will ever know. B beat.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I already signed the contract.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: (Smiling, pleased:) What contract? Do you want the last piece of baklava? Avner shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Smart decision, you should avoid sweets. After all you just signed away your dental insurance. In the movie, the following scene comes before the one th just concluded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane’s half-empty, the other passengers are asleep. Avner has a row to himself. He‘’s sitting by the window, staring out. He switches on the light overhead. His reflection appears. Another face appears in the reflectio apparently right behind Avner, a man in a stocking mask. Avner stares into the other man’s dark eyes, veiled but visible through the mesh.

dialogues.speaker: MUNICH -
dialogues.text: The eight intruders are shoving as a group against a door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (STAGE/ICE RINK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of the door, Yossef Gutfreund is shouti to wake up the others. Behind him, Tuvia Sokolovsky is breaking the glass in a window and crawling out. Finally the fedayeen succeed in forcing the door open. Guttfreund falls te the ground.  46 47 48
INT. APARTMENT 1 AT 31 CONNOLLYSTRASSE — 4:30AM {STAGE/IC

dialogues.speaker: RINK
dialogues.text: Moshe Weinberg, the wrestling coach, rushes at Issa, who entering his room; Weinberg slashes Issa across the chest with a fruit knife he’s found lying nearby. Tony, enterin the room behind Issa, fires a pistol and shoots Weinberg the face. Severely wounded, he hurls himself at the man w shot him, dropping the knife on the ground.

Issa, Paolo, Abu-Halah, Badran, Kader, and Salah, brandis AK47s, are tying up Springer, Shapira, Schorr, Spitzur an Guttfreund, screaming at them, interrogating them, asking the whereabouts of other Israeli athletes. Weinberg is be herded out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (STAGE/ICE RINK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, Badran, Paolo, Kader and Samir are rousting out of Berger, Tsobari, Slavin, Halfin, Romano, on crutches, and Freedman. Weinberg, face bleeding and bandaged with a sca is leaning against a wall.

The athletes from apartment three, hands raised, are bein led into apartment one by the fedayeen. Weinberg, behind Tsobari, shouts at the others to run, and as he does he t and smashes one of the fedayeen, Badran , in the face, tearing a gash in Badran’s face, knocking out several tee Badran falls. One of the fedayeen fires a pistol into Weinberg’s head, killing him. Tsobari escapes out a door which leads to the underground carpark.
Romano, dropping his crutches, also runs, limping painful into apartment one. He grabs Weinberg’s dropped knife as runs up the spiral staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 50 51 33. At the top of the stairs he encounters one of the fedayee Salah, who is wearing a stocking mask. With great force Romano stabs Salah in his forehead. He screams, spraying blood, and staggers, the knife sticking straight out of h forehead. Romano runs into the room in which the first fi athletes are captive (Schorr Springer Shapira Shpitzer an Guttfireund). As Romano bursts into the room, covered in blood, he is confronted by Abu Hallah who fires killing Romano who fal heavily into the middle of the room, while the bound athl inside cower from the gunfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (STAGE/ICE RINK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tony, Kader and Paulo drag the body of Moshe Weinberg out the sidewalk. They drop his corpse face-down on the sidew They run back into the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the plane’s window, the dawn is breaking in a thi red line on the horizon. Avner’s staring at his reflectio He turns out the overhead light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of the bank.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVA
dialogues.text: Avner is in a private room in the vault. He has an empty knapsack with him. One large safety deposit box and five smaller ones are on the table. There's a pile of rubber bands on the table. Avner opens the large box. It’s packed with stacks of US dollars. He removes ten stacks of bills from the box, a great deal of cash, and puts them in the knapsack. Then h opens one of the smaller boxes. It’s got a modest amount cash. He closes the smaller box, leaving all the money inside. He makes sure all boxes are locked. He is fastidi Holding his knapsack, he pushes a button at the side of t deor of the room. The door is opened immediately by a ver pretty, very Swiss bank official, who smiles at Avner as ushers him out of the room. He smiles back at her.  52 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a handsomely furnished apartment, solid furniture. C Hans, and Steve and Robert are meeting for the first time Everyone’s dressed casually except for Hans, who wears a and tie. Behind them is a table set for dinner. Avner emerges from the kitchen, wearing an apron, carryin large steaming brisket on a tray.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: A team leader who cooks! What a luxury!

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Years in the kibbutz kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to Avner: )} You've done this before?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Done what? » Sit. Everyone sits. Avner starts serving.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Because I joined Mossad ten minutes ago and I’m, I want to kill every one of these pigs but -- so, so some of you have training in --

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (pointing to Hans:) He sells antigues.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Right here in Frankfurt! It’s a front, but successful, I’ma documents and identities specialist with an sharp eye for early Danish modern.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I make toys.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: i thought you made bombs.  35. eS ROBERT Toys. In Brussels. But don’t worry, I’ve been studying how to make bombs!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to Avner: ) Is it Ali Hassan Salameh? Is that our job? We're here to kill the guy who planned Munich, am I right? Everyone eats.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: After the Six Day War, I joined Mossad because I needed to do something, you know? For my people. When my son came along I thought, well. I’ve made a new Jew.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: My wife‘s expecting.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Mazeltov! e@ CARL AND HANS ROBERT Mazeltov! That’s wonderful! When?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: A couple of months from now.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Think we’ll be done by then? Silence. Eating. No one wants to talk about this.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: It‘s strange, isn’t it? To think of oneself as an assassin?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Then think of yourself as something else.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: A soldier. In a war. Avner nods. Carl raises his glass to Hans, a toast.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Right, and you know how to shoot, e to assassinate people? Right? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 36. STEVE (cont'd) I mean, mazels on the baby and all that, that's just great but, but -- (to Robert) You make dolis, in a toyshop, and (to Hans) You shop for sofas and (Carl) I don’t know what you do --

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I worry.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: His ulcers have ulcers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to Avner:) So why’d they make you team leader?

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Because he really knows how to cook a brisket.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You‘re only the wrong guy for the ‘job if you screw it up. ¢ So let's not screw it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a high angle above the table: The table, lit by lamp has been cleared for work. The eleven photographs of the targeted Palestinians have been laid out on the table as were in scene 34.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: There are seven hard targets, military, armed. And four soft targets, poets, loudmouth intellectuals. Each has blood on his hands, each is responsible in some way for Munich. They examine the photos as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: How do we find our targets?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: That‘s the tricky part. No help from Mossad. A beat. Everyone considers this.  37.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Let's not waste time with the Arab coffeehouses and mosques. Informers tattling on informers.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: And the money we pay the informers gets funneled straight back to Black September.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: The fedayeen in Munich had AK-47s, fake passports, plane tickets. Who paid for all that?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: We're forbidden the Arab countries. We can’t go to Eastern Europe either.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Which leaves the European radical Left.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Palestinian sympathizers, and penetrable. Sloppy, even.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Money leaves trails. And it opens pathways. The group continues to discuss, Avner watching. Steve, Robert and Hans are exchanging ideas. We don’t hear the dialogue; as Avner watches, we hear the sound of a phone being dialled, ringing, someone picking up.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Andreas? Guess who?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Holy shit!

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Surprised?

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You punched me! You broke my jaw!  54 55 38.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: That was ten years ago. (in ENGLISH) And you were screwing my girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apartment is an elegant shambles; clearly expensive, remnants of costly furnishings, but also posters from str and marches and a portrait of Fanon thumbtacked on smoke- dingy walls. Books are strewn everywhere. Andreas and his girlfriend, yvonne, are smoking pot; Avne pretending to, but he isn't. There's also beer and wine. Yvonne is holding Herbert Marcuse's "Reason and Revolutio

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: The problem is considering right and wrong as ethical questions. Marcuse says Hegel's "Philosophy of Right" doesn’t place "wrong" in a moral category, it's --

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Then it's OK to kill someone who --

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Free Will necessarily creates wrong. That‘s in Marx, the blind anarchy of capitalism. You have to be willing to re-consider, right, wrong, they’re just ways of talking about a terrible struggle, parts of an equation, a dialectic -- strip the sentiment out and try to come to terms with historical forces external to us and indifferent to moral category.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: {over Yvonne, after “You have to be willing etc”:) She's amazing, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: {over Yvonne: } I don't know what she's talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over Yvonne:) Neither do I but she's dead sexy, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Fuck you, pig. {to Avner, in GERMAN: ) You don't read much, huh.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: What sort of business do you... Andreas re-lights a joint he's holding and tokes it.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: I work for some Americans.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Rich Americans, right? Avner takes the joint out of Andreas's fingers, puts it i his mouth but doesn’t toke. He takes an enormous wad of m from his pocket. He cracks up, as does Andreas. ‘Yvonne p Marcuse down and takes the money from Avner’s hand, then joint from his mouth. She tokes and starts counting the money.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS
dialogues.text: Hey, Yvonne! Avner wants to get in your pants! He told me. Andreas takes the joint from Yvonne. He tokes.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (IN ENGLISH)
dialogues.text: T really miss you, man, you know, we really loved each other.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: That was, like, a long time ago, Man, we were in high school!

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: It's sixty thousand dollars, Avner. Avner starts to laugh again, as if he’s stoned, Andreas joining in. Yvonne takes the joint, tokes.  40.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: (to Yvonne) I have a few names, people I need to find. For my rich Americans. {in ENGLISE:) Give me my money, Yvonne. He reaches for it. She pulls away, hanging on to the mone

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: Are you Baader-Meinhof? Red Army Faction? What?

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: One hundred fifty.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: One hundred in cash. Avner takes a smaller wad of cash out of another pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: One hundred... thousand!                         Dollars?!

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: These people I'm looking for, you don’t know them.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: We might.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: You don't. But I think maybe you know people who would. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE, (GERMAN)
dialogues.text: And it's Americans? You work for -- Avner exhales. He takes a $5,000 bill out of the new wad.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: See? James Madison. American. Yvonne and Andreas look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: YVONNE
dialogues.text: We'll ask some friends.  56 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andreas and Avner are sitting at a table with Tony, a tou looking Italian man, mid-40s, very serious, plates of pas in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Hiding? The Arabs aren't hiding. Munich was a big success for them.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS
dialogues.text: Yeah, the implications of Munich for the struggle are incredibly, um

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: They got everyone’s attention. They're recruiting, Making plans. Give me a few names. Avner hesitates. They stare at one another. Andreas is ignored. _. TONY. on , . I can’t help if I don’t know who you're trying to find. We'll have to trust. You have to cross the line. {makes a little “come to me” gesture, leans in:) I trust you. You carry cash and you don't make speeches. Nowadays, everyone makes speeches. Like our friend Andreas. Talk talk talk. Tony gives Andreas‘s face a gentle slap. Andreas tries to pretend not to be insulted.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: So name me an Arab.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Abu Yussuf. Abu Daoud. Wael Zwaiter. Kemal Nasser. Tony nods noncommitally: “I’ve heard of them”

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Salameh.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Forget Salameh. Too hard.  42.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS
dialogues.text: {to Avner) Who are these guys? Why are you trying to find Arabs, it’s --

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Sixty thousand per name. Dollars.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: If it's good information.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: If it isn't good it doesn't cost. Wael Zwaiter’s here. In Rome. He just translated "The Arabian Nights” into Italian. Tomorrow there’s a reading. He’s broke. He has a retarded niece he calls every day in Damascus.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS
dialogues.text: {to Avner) Are you trying to join the PLO?

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: {to Andreas) We need to talk alone. Tony indicates Andreas should leave. Andreas looks to Avn who looks back at him, blank.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: {to Avner) And also maybe you need people to help with your work, cars, vans.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS
dialogues.text: (to Avner) Listen, be careful with this guy, he, they said he was dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: {to Andreas, softly, in

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN
dialogues.text: Go. I don't want to see you hurt, either.

dialogues.speaker: ANDREAS
dialogues.text: Hurt?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Tell anyone about this and, I don't know, just don't OK?  57-58 59 60 43. Andreas looks from Avner to Tony. The menace in Tony’s fa is unmistakable: “Or I will kill you.” Andreas, shocked, looks back at Avner. Avner nods to him to confirm the impression he’s just gotten from Tony. Andreas leaves. Avner watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: TONY
dialogues.text: Anything you need. We provide. Avner turns back to Tony, thinking. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I need receipts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A one-room apartment, windows tightly shuttered, though golden Roman afternoon light is leaking in. There are several mattresses on the floor, and street maps, surveillance photoes, documents, newspapers lie scattered about. Avner, Carl, Hans, Robert and Steve, dressed in th clothes they’ll wear during the hit, are kneeling on the floor in a circle. Cari holds four straws in his fist. Avner watches; the others draw straws. They compare. Robert has the shortest straw. The others look at him. He looks away, unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little courtyard patio restaurant outside the bookshop. thin Palestinian man, Wael Zwaiter, is standing facing a small crowd of Italians and Arabs. He is holding a copy o his newly-published translation of “1,001 Arabian Nights.

dialogues.speaker: ZWAITER
dialogues.text: What attracts me to the Scheherazade story, to what you in the West call “The Arabian Nights” ~ - well I am not an Arab. I am Palestinian. And why has a Palestinian poet worked for years translating “1,001 Arabian Nights” from the Arabic into Italian? Apart from the expectation of enormous riches, I mean? The audience laughs quietly.  61 62 63
Across the street, Carl is watching this performance.

dialogues.speaker: ZWAITER
dialogues.text: I love what this classic says about the power of narrative, the relationship of narrative to survival. As long as the girl Scheherazade tells a story, she stays alive. For her, the stories are from fantasy. The stories of my people are from memory. We tell them, over and over; to save ourselves from oblivion. You see? Narrative can have the power to conquer death. Zwaiter stands.

dialogues.speaker: ZWALTER
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming to my reading. Thank you for listening to me. The audience applauds politely. Zwaiter mingles with his audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little while later. The small crowd has gone and Zwaite is leaving. He walks down the street. Carl follows behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zwaiter is using a payphone, speaking softly. At the counter, Carl is buying an apple. Zwaiter hangs up the ph goes to the shelves and selects: a jar of maraschino cherries, some green-colored dish soap, a bottle of orang soda pop, a bottle of grape juice, a salami, bread, and fruit. He catches Carl’s eye as Carl leaves the store. Th smile and nod at one another, friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl emerges from the store, nods to Steve who is across street in a Flat, sitting next to a young Italian woman, looks bored. Steve nods back at Carl and drives off. Swaiter comes out of the store, carrying two brown paper with groceries. He walks down the street. Carl follows behind him.  64 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AR van enters the square. It pulls up next to a fountain the center of the square. Hans hops out. He looks around square. He spots Steve’s Fiat across the square, parked curbside by an apartment building. When Steve sees Hans get out of the van, he steps out of Fiat. Steve positions himself a few doorways away, steppi into the doorframe to strike a match, light a cigarette. bored Italian woman inside the Fiat drives away. Zwaiter enters the piazza with his groceries. As Zwaiter' entering, the van has moved from the fountain and is approaching the parking space previously occupied by the Fiat. As Zwaiter enters the building, Hans is stepping out of t van. Steve gets behind the van’s steering wheel and Hans takes up Steve's former position.

dialogues.speaker: AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The lobby is dark. Zwaiter opens the front door and steps inside. He juggles his grocery bag and reaches for the lo iight switch. He flicks the switch, and the light’s timer starts. Avner and Robert are standing between Zwaiter and the cur Staircase. Zwaiter looks at the two men, and they look at him. Everyone's blank for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Are you Wael Zwaiter?

dialogues.speaker: ZWAITER
dialogues.text: Yes? I’m sorry I -- IT -~

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Do you know why we're here? A beat. Zwaiter shakes his head "no,” confused. Robert an Avner draw their guns; Avner‘s gun gets caught momentaril his belt. %waiter is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Are you Wael --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: He said yes already, he -~  66 46.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I didn't hear him say that he -- Zwaiter walks slowly to Avner and puts his hand gently on Avner's gun; he tries carefully to lower it. Robert fires two shots, through the grocery bags and into Zwaiter's chest. Zwaiter looks at Robert, shocked. Then A fires, two shots, again through the shopping bags, which Zwaiter continue to hold. Zwaiter screams in pain, then drops to his knees, then falls flat on his face, crushing groceries in the bags. There’s a sound of bottle breaking Maraschino liquid, green soap, orange soda, grape juice, mixed with dark blood, spill out under Zwaiter. He tries roll over but can’t; he’s panting, sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: ZWAITER
dialogues.text: {almost inaudible: ) La, la. Aiuto, aiutec, please, please... He rolls over onte his back. Robert walks up close and fi another shot right into Zwaiter's chest. Avner does the s Zwaiter's already stopped moving. Dazed, they each fire again. —~ Robert and Avner stand over the body, guns out, breathing Suddenly the timer clicks the lights off. Avner swivels i the dark, gun at the ready. He slams the light switch on quickly locates, picks up and pockets the shell casings, counting to... seven. He looks for the eighth casing, the gives up. Robert is crouching over the body. He holds his hand over nose and mouth, smelling something terrible. He gags. Suddenly the lobby elevator shudders and jolts into life. Robert and Avner jump. Someone on an upper floor is descending

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Move. EXT. OUTSIDE ZWAITER’S APARTMENT BUILDING - LATE AFTERNOO Avner and Robert walk briskly out of the building. The va is waiting. On the side of the van, a sign:"Maurizio and Sons, Gardening” Avner and Robert yank open the van’s rea door and tumble in. Hans is inside, waiting, and Steve is the driver’s seat. They pull the door closed and the van drives off.  67 68 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans, Robert and Avner are seated on sacks of soil and fertilizer on the floor of the van. Gardening supplies an ornaments are ail around them, swaying as the van drives through Roman streets. Everyone inside is adrenalated and freaked out.

dialogues.speaker: HE SHAT HIMSELF
dialogues.text: Everyone stops shouting. They sit in silence as the van sways. They take in the interior of the van: all around them, wrapped in clear plastic, are cheap painted plaster Virgin Mary garden statues, each holding a baby Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Hallelujah. It's a sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several hours later. A waitress is serving food. Awful bouncy Italian music is piped in. Hans, Steve, Avner and Robert are drinking wine, a little sloshed. There are no other customers. Hans is poring over a pile of small pieces of paper -- receipts. Steve drinks, happy; Robert is drunker and glum Avner is tense, watching the door, waiting for something. Carl comes in, looking very tired. This is what Avner was waiting for. Carl sits next te Avner. The others watch.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Well, what do you want me to say? He’s dead.  48. Carl reaches in his pocket and takes out a bullet casing. tosses it to Avner. Avner pockets it, Silence.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Have some wine. We're celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: That old Pesach story. The angels are rejoicing because the Egyptians have just drowned in the Red Sea.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I didn’t say we're rejoicing. We're celebrating.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: And God says to the angels "Why are you celebrating? I've just killed a multitude of my children." Hans folds up the pile of receipts.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: (to Avner) Mr. Zwaiter. He cost us, by my calculation, roughly $352,000.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (to Cari) You didn't finish the story. The angels respond to God. They say "We're celebrating, God, because when people hear what happened to the Egyptians they'll understand Your point."

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Which was?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Don't fuck with the Jews. I don’t know about the rest of you but I’m not celebrating, I’m goddamned rejoicing. Avner raises his glass.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: To the martyrs. The others raise their glasses. They toast, and drink, sorrow descends as they remember. and a  69 70 49. Steve gets up and goes to the waitress. He grabs her and starts to waltz her around. She laughs, enjoying it. The other four watch this, then look at one another. Avner ge to his feet, then pulls Rebert up, and they start to danc Robert heavy, stumbling a little. Hans joins them, throwi his arms around their shoulders. Avner pulls Carl in. Ste leaves the waitress, joins the others. They dance a kind heavy-footed hora out of time to the bad Italian pop. As they dance, awkward, self-conscious, a closeness settles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small side street in the Marais. Tony and Avner are standing outside a shop, waiting. Louis, a Frenchman, slightly younger than Avner, arrives foot. Tony introduces the two. It’s all quite friendly. Tony whispers something to Louis, then gets into @ car waiting by the curb. The car drives off. Louis takes Avner’s arm and leads him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner is shopping with Louis. Louis has a shopping list a is filling a macrame carry sack with vegetable.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Our service has been satisfactory?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Pricey.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: A Jew and a Frenchman. We could haggle forever.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I'm not a Jew. Louis nods, smiling. He shows Avner the shopping list.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: What do you suppose a “ramson” is?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: It's a kind of wild leek. Not in season. Garlic will do.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: My papa sometimes loses track of the seasons. I know nothing about food, why does he make me shop?  50. Louis hands Avner the shopping list. As they walk and tal Avner hands Louis vegetables, consulting the list. Louis puts them in the carry sack.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You‘re wondering if I'm French Intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Or CIA. Or KGB.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Or an agent with a profitable sideline in information. I could be anybody. You could be anybody too. Identity: That's the boring part. Here's what isn't boring: as long as you don't work for any government -~

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I’m in private business.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Rich Americans, I heard. I'm in private business too. My family. We can locate almost anyone, for anyone, anywhere, and we're ideologically promiscuous. We love everyone. Or hate everyone, I get my feelings confused. If you're not working for any government: We know or we find. We don't find, you don't pay. Louis takes a photo out of his bookbag. He slides the pho over to Avner. Avner looks down at it.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mahmoud Hamshari. A beat. Avner turns the picture over. There's information written on the reverse. Louis hands Avner a series of bla and white photos, showing Hamshari leaving his apartment, getting into a car, talking with colleagues in front of t Arab League headquarters. Avner examines these as Louis talks.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: He’s one of your famous names, yes, Monsieur...?  72

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Franz Storsch. Avner hands Louis a folded copy of Le Monde. Louis looks inside, removes a fat envelope, puts it in the carry sack amidst the vegetables.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Please call me Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a long table behind microphones, facing a mob of repor and cameras, Jamal al-Gashey, Adnan al-Gashey and Mohamme Safady, three of the Palestinians from Munich, are seated their lawyer standing behind them. The press conference i in English, with someone translating over into French. ai Gashey is reading a statement.

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL AL-GASHEY
dialogues.text: What we did in Munich is the beginning, only the beginning. If justice is not done for our people, flor. the Palestinian: people, .further acts of violence, the people’s justice, will occur.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A television screen: Al-Gashey concludes his statement:

dialogues.speaker: JAMAL AL-GASHEY
dialogues.text: We are not acting alone. There are thousands, millions with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans, Carl and Steve, in overcoats, suitcases behind them having just arrived, are standing behind a couch on which Avner and Robert are seated. They're watching the television.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: A Lufthansa jet was hijacked coming from Damascus. The hijackers demanded the release of the three killers who survived Munich. The Germans agreed. Instantly. They're free. See? They're in Libya now.  52. 722K cUT TO: 772A The television screen, which shows an enormous crowd of people in Tripoli gathered to welcome the three fedayeen. 72 CONT ‘aT TO: 72 CONT'D.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to Carl) No qualms about rejoicing on their side, huh? Look at that! They’re movie stars! {to Avner) We should go to Tripoli and kill them.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: We don't go to Arab countries. We stick with the names we've been given. Silence. Avner produces a photo. Everyone looks at it and then looks back to the television, torn. .

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Mahmoud Hamshari.

dialogues.speaker: 72B CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: On the television,

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: (OS, from the TV) What do you think you achieved by killing the Israeli athletes? As Adnan al-Gashey answers in Arabic, his lawyer translat

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: We have... made our voice heard by the world. 73 INT. MAHMOUD HAMSHARI'S APARTMENT, PARIS — DAY 73 Hamshari, 50s, dapper, professorial, is seated, being interviewed by a journalist who is revealed to be Robert, smoking a cigarette, playing a tape of the released terrorists’ lawyer saying:  53.

dialogues.speaker: LAWYER
dialogues.text: We have made our voice heard by the universe, or... the world, who was not hearing before. Robert clicks off the tape recorder.

dialogues.speaker: MAHMOUD HAMSHARI
dialogues.text: What he meant by this is that the world will begin hearing us. We are for twenty-four years the world's largest refugee population, our homes taken from us, living in camps, no future, no food, nothing decent for our children. Mme. Hamshari walks in, smiling at Robert.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Was the attack in Munich justified?

dialogues.speaker: MAHMOUD HAMSHARI
dialogues.text: The PLO condemns attack on civilians --

dialogues.speaker: MAHMOUD HAMSHART MME. HAMSHART
dialogues.text: ~~ though for twenty-four Tell your newspaper that, years our civilians have been about, about all the years attacked by the Israelis. and years of Palestinian blood, spilled by Israel, and who mourns for us?

dialogues.speaker: MAHMCUD HAMSHARI
dialogues.text: Israel just bombed two refugee camps in Syria and Lebanon, two hundred people killed, right after Munich they did this, so is that --

dialogues.speaker: MME. HAMSHART
dialogues.text: It did not begin in Munich. And where does it end? How will it ever end?

dialogues.speaker: MAHMOUD HAMSHART, (IN ARABIC)
dialogues.text: Please, Marie-Claude, whose interview is this?

dialogues.speaker: MME. HAMSHARI, (FRENCH)
dialogues.text: It‘s your interview, I’m just pointing out something that -~-  74 75

dialogues.speaker: MAHMOUD HAMSHARI
dialogues.text: I’m perfectly capable of covering all the essential -- Robert. suddenly looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh, Damn! Doctor, may I, please, your telephone, may I... I must call my editor, I'm sorry --

dialogues.speaker: MAHMOUD HAMSHART
dialogues.text: Oh yes, yes you said you... Yes, this way, please, here's the phone... Hamshari leads Robert to the phone. He leaves Robert dial the phone and goes to another room, speaking in French to wife. As Robert dials he lifts the phone and writes down on his the model serial number. He places the phone on the pad; outlines the phone's base, then measures its height with fingers and makes marks on the pad corresponding to this measurement. A young girl comes into the room, sits down at the piano starts doing practice pieces, shyly watching Robert while plays. Robert draws in deep on his cigarette, getting her attention. He pops his eyes, puffs his cheeks, then blast smoke through his nose, a dragon! The girl rolls her eyes suppressing a smile, gets up from the piano and leaves th room, trying to look completely unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mme. Hamshari and the girl, Amina, carrying a schoolbag, leave the building and get into a parked car. Across the street, a van is parked, marked with the Franc Telecom logo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, Carl, Robert and Avner, dressed in France Telecom repair uniforms, Steve at the wheel. They watch Mme Hamsh and Amina drive away, , on their way to Amina's school.  76 55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one's home. Suddenly the front door pops cpen, Robert forcing it slightly, a bent wire in the lock. Carl stands behind him clutching a valise, very very gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You don't have to baby it, it can't go off unless I push... Robert takes a bakelite box with a teggle switch on it ou his pocket. He flicks the switch. Carl drops the valise. Robert catches it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the switch only works after someone picks up the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (badly scared, VERY angry?) . That isn't... funny you stupid --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Sorry, sorry...

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I hope you know what you're doing. Robert goes to Hamshari's phone. Carl and Avner watch as starts to install the phone bomb.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (with a slight smile, quietly, to Carl:) Do you think I know what I'm doing? Carl considers this.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: This man, we don’t know what he did, specifically?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Hamshari arranged the attempt to kill Ben-Gurion in Copenhagen a few years ago. He’s organizing for Fatah in France.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Organizing.  77 56.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: And in Tel Aviv, they showed you the evidence for this?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Not evidence, no, it was more... “Here’s the story.” I believe them. Absolutely. Don‘t you? Carl doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: This is war, a crisis, you don’t always have to, to...

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Think.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
