dialogues.text: crutinize every -~ Yeah, think. You want to wire Ephraim demanding evidence, you’re on your own.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Good. {to Carl:) Don‘t think about it. Robert demonstrates: He lifts the receiver on the phone, a light on a remote control device lights up.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I see the light, I flip the switch. And... well, you know. EXT. PHONE BOOTH, AROUND THE CORNER FROM HAMSHARI’S APART

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING, PARIS
dialogues.text: Carl is in the phone booth, pretending te talk on the pho depressing the hang-up button. At the next corner, Avner is at a kiosk, browsing through magazines.

dialogues.speaker: 77D
dialogues.text: INT. INSIDE A FIAT, THE STREET IN FRONT OF HAMSHARI’S TIA

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT, PARIS
dialogues.text: Around the corner, down the street, across from the apartment, a Fiat is parked. Steve is in the driver’s sea Robert's in the passenger seat, holding the remote contro device on his lap. Hans is in the back seat. EXT. IN FRONT OF HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT BUILDING - MORNING Mme. Hamshari and Amina come out and get into a car parke front of the building. Amina is carrying a schoolbag. Avner up the street at the kiosk is watching. He nods to Carl, whe nods back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans, Robert and Steve watch Mme. Hamshari and Amina driv away. Steve looks up the street at Avner at the kiosk. Avner, looking up at Carl, takeé his hat off.’

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Our leader has doffed his chapeau... M. Hamshari, the grim reaper is now dialing your number. EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT ~- MORNING 7 A large moving truck pulls up, completely cutting off the Fiat’s view of the apartment building. Avner runs down the street, past the truck, looking in at bored driver, who’s obviously settled in for a long stop; then he crosses the street to the Fiat.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Is it blocking the signal, will the remote work? Robert holds up the remote device; the toggle switch is taped,

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don‘t know, I... we'll see, probably it’1ll be OK.  775

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Go tell the truck, give him some cash and get him to move.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Get back to your position, you ean’t start improvising now, go back to the corner!

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It’s a powerful radio, um, thing, it, it’s fine, I think. While Avner and the others are talking, they don't see Mm Hamshari’‘s car, on the other side of the truck has come down the street, in reverse. Amina gets out of the idling car and runs back into the apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner returns to the kiosk; as he does he nods to Carl. Carl starts to dial the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amina runs up the stairs. EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT - MORNING TI Carl continues to dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amina runs to her apartment door. EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT ~ MORNING 77 Carl finishes dialling. The phone starts to ring. INT. IN THE BEDROOM IN HAMSHARI‘'S APARTMENT -— MORNING 7 Hamshari is putting on his shirt as Amina runs into the r

dialogues.speaker: AMINA, (ARABIC)
dialogues.text: Mommy forgot her glasses.
The phone rings. She goes to her mother’s vanity and take pair of glasses from a drawer. She runs to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: AMINA, (ARABIC)
dialogues.text: I'll get it, Daddy. She picks up the phone. A slight hum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, hearing the phone being lifted, raise his finger as signal to Avner. Avner looks down the street to the front door of the apartment building. He sees Mme. Hamshari’s car. It registers that Amina is no longer in the car. Avner shoot gauick panicked glance up at the window of Hamshari’s apartment, realizing suddenly what's happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl hears someone pick up the phone. He starts to ask if it’s Hamshari when he hears Amina’s voice. AMINA‘'S VOICE Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The indicator light on Robert's remote lights up. Robert starts to move the tape off the toggle switch. He can’t g the tape off. EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT - MORNING TI Avner runs towards the Fiat. Behind him, across the stree Carl has dropped the receiver and is running as well acro the street towards the Fiat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is fumbling, having trouble getting the tape off t detonator switch. Steve and Hans are anxiously watching h INT. IN THE HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT ~ MORNING TTP Amina is holding the phone.  779

dialogues.speaker: AMINA
dialogues.text: Hello? Hello? {to her father:) No one is saying anything. Hamshari approaches the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert has peeled the tape off and puts his thumb on the switch. Suddenly Carl and Avner appear, pounding on the car’s closed windows. Hans reaches over and stops Robert' thumb with his hand. Carl and Avner are frozen, pressed against the windows. Avner draws his hand across his throat, meaning “abort.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amina looks up to her father.

dialogues.speaker: AMINA, (ARABIC)
dialogues.text: Nobody is saying anything? Hamshari takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: HAMSHARI
dialogues.text: Hello? (in ARABIC:) Hello? He hangs up. EXT. HAMSHART’S STREET - MORNING 778 Amina comes out of the building and gets into the car, handing her mother a pair of sunglasses, which her mother puts on as she drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans Robert and Steve inside the van and Carl and Avner outside on the pavement watch Mme. Hamshari and Amina dri away. The other four all turn to Avner, who looks up at t Hamshari apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 78-91 92 INT. IN THE BEDROOM IN HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT - MORNING 770 Hamshari is tying his tie as the phone rings. He looks at The phone rings again. He answers it.

dialogues.speaker: HAMSHART
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Mahmoud Hamshari? EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE HAMSHARI’S APARTMENT -MORNING 77W The sound of an explosion, but dull -~ people look up, confused. The glass in the window of Hamshari's apartment seems to buige outwards. Thousands of cracks appear; the glass holds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on a child’s wind-up toy, a tin clown which roll a ball across a tabletop, moving beautifully till it lose its balance and falis over. Robert, thoroughly wretched, picks up the toy, pries it open and tinkers with the weig inside. Steve's watching TV and flipping through a magazine. Avne is grinding herbs in a pestle, preparing dinner. Hans is again working on the receipts. It’s silent. Carl arrives.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: He's at L'Hopital Cochin. I don't know how badly we hurt him, they aren't saying.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: (to Robert: } Why did you put a goddamned firecracker in that phone?!  33 94 95 96

dialogues.speaker: ROEERT
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to blow up the building! What do you want from me?!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: An Arab corpse. Robert goes back to his work, miserable. Hans works on th receipts. He finishes.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Another two hundred thousand dollars, more or less, to eliminate target number two.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: If he's been eliminated. We should stick with guns.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: No one notices a shooting. Bombs accomplish a double objective: Eliminating targets, and terrifying the terrorists.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: That only works when the bombs work. Robert stands abruptly, grabs his coat and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Stay! That's an order! Robert leaves, closing the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl is on the phone. A television is on, and he’s watchi it as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: They discovered seven in a mail room near the embassy in, ah, Earl's court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detectives and soldiers, some with guns, two holding bomb sniffing dogs on leashes, are looking on while an army sa head-to toe in canvas and wicker armor, with great care i using tongs to extract another manila envelope from a stu mail bin. He places the envelope on the floor, alongside others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner is talking on the phone to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I guess they missed one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handsome brick mansion at the end of a courtyard off a guiet London street. The Israeli flag is flying.

dialogues.speaker: CARL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Right after Channukah, so I guess there was a big pile-up of mail, and they got careless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attache for Agricultural imports, Dr. Ami Sachori, is standing at his desk. He is sorting through a large pile mail and looking over a report at the same time. He picks a siightly-larger-than-letter size manila envelope. He te it open. The envelope explodes, hurling Sachori in the ai over his desk.  164 105 106 107 ioe 64.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl on the phone, watching the television. On the TV, th Israeli ambassador to Britain.

dialogues.speaker: THE ISRAELI AMBASSADOR
dialogues.text: It has become much easier for these terrorist groups to operate in Europe. They take advantage of your open societies and your hospitality. And, ah, we believe that unless there is, there are strong concerted anti-terrorist measures, this menace will grow for you as it has for us.

dialogues.speaker: CARL THE ISRAELI AMBASSADOR
dialogues.text: They’ve found other letters And, ah, there should be no in Israel of course, Canada, sympathy for these evil and Argentina, Vienna, Kinshasa, perverted men -- that is the Paris and Brussels. Dozens of message of Munich, which ha them, mostly mailed from the been reaffirmed by the murde Netherlands. It’s ail Black in my embassy this morning. September.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner is on the phone to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: It’s a response, then. To Hamshari.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: And to Zwaiter. They're talking to us. We’re in dialogue now. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: In New York, I‘m checking on a lead. I'll call you back.  109 110 65. Avner hangs up. He walks away from the phone. The sign on the phone booth is in Hebrew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Israeli customs officer is examining a West German passport.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMS AGENT
dialogues.text: What brings you to Israel, Mr. Storsch?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Business. And to see the Holy Sepulcher. The agent hands Avner his passport.

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMS AGENT
dialogues.text: Have a pleasant stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner's mother, a woman in her 50s, disappointed, unhappy face, is waiting with Avner, who is a wreck. Other expect fathers are waiting too.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Are you going to see your father?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (shaking his head “no") Why is this taking so long?!?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: It isn’t fast. We have the best hospitals in the world. When you were born, your father was elsewhere. I was alone.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: He was in prison.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Should you be here? Aren’t you on duty?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You going to turn me in? How is he?  iil 66.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I don't visit your father so much. Wilma lets him yell at her all the time. She depresses me.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I'm managing, don’t worry about me.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Ma...

dialogues.speaker: AVNER'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I'm proud of what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You don't know what I'm doing. They look at each other. Avner looks exhausted, and sad.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER'S MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I look at you, I know everything I need to know. INT. DAPHNA'S HOSPITAL ROOM lil Avner and Daphna and Geula, the baby.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: She's frighteningly ugly.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: She takes after you. He stands, walks to the door of the room, looks through t little window in the door at his mother, who is sitting i chair in the hallway, looking lonely and grim. He goes back to Daphna’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I want you to move. For a time. I’ve arranged a place, for us, in Brooklyn. I can't come back here again, not for... I don’t know. I can see you there more often, and her. Daphna looks at Geula.  67.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have my family here, and your parents.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You want my parents to help raise her? Look what they did to me.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: Don't you want your daughter to be an Israeli, Avner?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: She’1ll always be an Israeli.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: Not in Brooklyn. She'll just be another homeless Jew. She strokes his face.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: You‘re not so terrible.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER .
dialogues.text: Io can’t do what I’m doing if I can’t see you, I can’t...

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t do it, then. Avner, this is our home.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You‘re the only home I've ever had. Daphna cracks up.

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: Oh, man, that is so corny! She can‘t stop laughing.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: It wasn’t easy to say that!

dialogues.speaker: DAPHNA
dialogues.text: T bet! God damn. Why'd IT have to marry a sentimentalist? You’re ruining my life!  112 113 114 68.

dialogues.speaker: OLYMPIC, ON THE CYPRUS COAST NEAR NICOSIA
dialogues.text: Hans, Steve and Avner are watching Hussein Abad al-Chir, business suit, sunglasses and a checkered kaffiyeh, stepp into a limousine accompanied by three men with Russian fa Hans shows the others a photo. They look from the photo t the man getting in the car.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Uh oh, waistline bulge, he has a gun.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: As do the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: It‘s definitely him. HANS os Hussein Abad al~Chir. His room is next to Israeli newlyweds. They're marrying in Cyprus because she's not Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: {mock horror) A mixed marriage! A shonde!

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: OK, yeah, but you now, let’s not blow them up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Robert‘s making the bomb. They have nothing to fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The curtains are drawn. Lights intensely illuminate Rober at a table wiring six bombs together. He has a checklist a hand-drawn diagram near him on the floor, which he cons as he wires. Steve, Hans, Carl and Avner are watching.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The KGB brings him home every evening. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBERT (cont'd) He turns on the light, he undresses, he turns off the light, he gets into bed. We blow up the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: I knew a field agent who got too scared to sleep in his bed. So every night he slept on the floor of his closet. He still does. Every night. Sleeps in closets.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Be sure to include that anecdote in your memoirs, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: £ al-Chir sleeps in his closet we're in trouble. If he gets into bed, his weight arms the device. When we see his lights go out, I wait a bit, hit the remote and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is holding up the mattress of the bed, sweating und its sagging weight, while Robert, on his knees, is carefu placing the bombs, in their frame, under the mattress, an wiring the detonators to a wire that dangles out over the bedframe with a lightbulb on the end of it. Carl guards t door, gun drawn. A light knocking outside on the door. Everyone freezes. C opens it and admits Avner.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I checked in to the room next door.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: There are balconies. When I see him get in bed I'll signal by switching off the light.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: If the bomb‘s too powerful you could be killed.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: That won't happen, right?  70.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Robert?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (concentrating, not listening: ) It won't, no. Robert helps Steve lower the mattress very slowly onto th bomb. Avner and Carl watch, not breathing. The mattress i now resting on the bomb. Rebert checks the lightbulb. It’ dark. He smiles, nods. He motions to Steve and they raise the mattress again. He makes adjustments on the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: (softly, to Avner) A boy or a girl? Avner looks at him, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: A girl.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Mazeltov, Avner. Avner nods, pleased, missing his family.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Did you see the papers this morning? News from Paris. Dr. Hamshari succumbed to his wounds. He's dead. So again, mazeltov, Avner. Robert and Steve lower the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Now someone has to test it.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Test it?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Lie on the bed. If the bomb’s placed correctly the bulb will light. So who wants to test it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: {to Robert: } Why don’t you test it?  116

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: It won’t blow up. (a beat) Prove that you trust me. One of you, get in the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Steve, you do it. Steve looks at Robert and flings himself in the air and o the mattress. The bulb lights.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Avner is standing on the balcony. The room next to his is dark, and the room to the right of that room is lit. Belo him, on the street, a car honks its horn twice. He goes t the railing and looks down. A limo is pulling up. Wearing a bathrobe, the young bride in the room one over Avner's comes out on her balcony for a smoke. She sees Av and smiles at him. Her husband comes out, clad only in pa bottoms. He nods to Avner, then:puts his arms around his bride. They look at to sea; he kisses her neck. Avner wan to look and look and is embarrassed and looks away. The lights in the room next to his are switched on. Al~-C is in his room. Silence, the sound of a brief phone call in Arabic. The bridegroom is whispering something to the bride. Avner, horny, lonely, stares at them. Al-Chir steps out onto his balcony. Avner is startled. Al-Chir nods at the bridegroom and bride. They smile at h and then the bridegroom leads the bride back into their r Laughter comes from inside, followed by music. Their ligh go out. Moans and groans start to drift out. Avner stares, al-Chi stares, both men fascinated, at the dark open doorway of newlyweds’ room. Al-Chir turns to smile at Avner.

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL
dialogues.text: Good evening.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, good evening.  72.

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL-CHIR
dialogues.text: Beautiful night. Where are you from? I can’t place the --

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Koln.

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL
dialogues.text: Yes? I wouldn’t have guessed, it, I thought perhaps a Swede. I taught in Sweden. Near Eastern languages.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL-CHIR
dialogues.text: Teaching Lebanese immigrant women how to clean houses in Swedish. Surprisingly remunerative. And such a beautiful country! The sounds of love-making increase in volume.

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL
dialogues.text: Were you here last night?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: No, I just checked in, just arrived,

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL-CHIR
dialogues.text: Don't plan to sleep. They keep at it till dawn. I loved Sweden, I've loved all the places I've lived, but there's nothing like the Mediterranean. If you were born within sight of it you can't live without it. Al-Chir takes a pack of cigarettes out of his jacket pock He takes out a cigarette, offers one to Avner who shakes head “no.”

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Where were you born?

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL-
dialogues.text: A town that no longer exists. Al-Chir puts the cigarette in his mouth and pats his pock leoking for a match. Avner takes out a lighter, holds it towards Al-Chir, who leans over his side of the balcony.  i17 118 73. Avner flicks the lighter and, using his hand te shield th flame from the wind, lights al-Chir‘s cigarette. Al-Chir nods thanks, inhales, exhales.

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL-CHIR
dialogues.text: But the sea is still here. The sex sounds from the newlyweds’ suite become downright raucous.

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL-CHIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There! For hours! Take a sleeping pill if you have one. You want to borrow one of mine?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I can sleep through anything.

dialogues.speaker: HUSSEIN ABAD AL-CHIR
dialogues.text: Pleasant dreams. He goes in his room. Then the lights go off. Avner moves closer to the balcony railing where it abuts hotel wall. He hauls himself up, then leans in. He hears Chir moving about, singing softly to himself. A tap runni Peeing. A toilet flush. Then the sound of a man lowering himself into bed with a sigh. Avner leans further in. He can just see the foot of the b and al-Chir's legs sliding under the bedclothes. He lower himself back to his own balcony, goes in his room, switch off the light. A beat, and then an enormous explosion; the wall Avner's shares with al-Chir's is pushed in and falls over, intact knocking Avner back onto his bed. The fan in the ceiling above is sheered off and falls, nearly hitting Avner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke and flames explode from ai-Chir’s room across his balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glass and plaster and stone rain down on the street, boun off a car in which Steve and Carl are sitting. Robert. and Hans are in the car behind Steve and Carl‘s c Hans driving, Robert holding the detonator. The car lurch forward, preparing to drive off as planned.  119 120 It screeches to a stop amidst the rain of debris as Carl jumps out of the first car. Carl slams his hand on the ho of Hans’s car.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Go! Hans pulls the car out and drives off as Carl runs to the hotel. INT. AVNER'S ROOM, HOTEL OLYMPIC -NIGHT i119 Avner is trapped in a space between his bed and the wall, which is now leaning against the opposing wall, pictures it dangling from their hooks. Avner struggles to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hall is thick with smoke. Avner, covered in plaster dust, coughing, is emerging from his room. To the left of al-Chir's doorless room, the newlyweds for their door and stumble out, naked, covered in dust. He's bleeding. froma nasty cut.on his forehead, and she's momentarily blinded by plaster dust and smoke. The groom turns to Avner.

dialogues.speaker: GROOM
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: GROOM
dialogues.text: What... what happened                        !

dialogues.speaker: BRIDE
dialogues.text: Iocan't see! The groom wipes at her eyes with his thumbs. Avner goes i their room and comes out with sheets. They wrap themselve

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Get downstairs, the stairs, here. He pushes them toward the stairs. The door to the stairwe opens and Carl, carrying a fire extinguisher, rushes past Avner, their eyes meeting. Avner leads the couple to the stairs as Carl runs into al-Chir's room.  122 122 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smoke and dust. The room is utterly destroyed. Carl blast the fire extinguisher at small flames. He gropes for the light switch, flicks it. The crystal chandelier, a burnt and twisted mess of metal hanging by wires, lights up -- one or two bulbs are intac An arm and a section of torso are dangling from the chandelier. Carl switches off the light as Avner comes in. Carl wipes the extinguisher clean with his handkerchief, then drops on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team is huddled over a thermos on the deck. They spea in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: It was toc powerful, it could have —

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Target number three. Outcome not in doubt!

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: {to Robert:) The ceiling in the lobby cracked! You nearly demolished the -- You could have killed Avner. And --

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The plastique wasn't what I asked for, it couldn't have been the grade I specified, someone changed the markings on the explosives.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE CARL
dialogues.text: What does it matter, we got (to Robert) Black September’s contact What do you mean, someone with the KGB! changed the -- (to Steve:) Shut up, please.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Louis provided the plastique, right?  123 76.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Yes. Why? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: (to Avner:) Why are we trusting him?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: We have no idea who he is.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: He's finding our targets.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Yes, but --

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Without him we’d be nowhere in this.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: The plastique was much more ..spowerful than what I requested. Someone changed the label.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: For all we know, Louis works for the PLO, and they’re using us to do internal housecleaning.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: That's --

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Whose fishing boat is this? Everyone looks at Avner.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Louis arranged it. Silence. Steve takes out his .22, undoes the safety, puts back in its holster. The boat sails on in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: STORE ON A FANCY STREET IN PARIS
dialogues.text: It's late and misty. There are no pedestrians. Avner is looking at a brightly lit and very beautiful Swedish-Mode kitchen set up for display.  i24 124 125 126

dialogues.speaker: 126A
dialogues.text: 127 7?. He's tired, but staring at the kitchen with real longing, eyes traveling over every inch of it, drinking in what at means: luxury, security, domesticity, Daphna -- everythin he’s aching for. Avner’s hungry, weary face is reflected by the glass. The kitchen dims and merges with another image, apparently reflected at first then growing in sharpness and solidity

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STORE ON A FANCY STREET IN PARIS — NIGHT Avner, watching in the glass, as the. scene of carnage fa away. Louis is standing next to Avner. He has an Alsatian by th leash. Avner turns to look at Louis, unfocused.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: There was nothing wrong with the explosive. Bomb makers are nervous, which is understandable.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER LOUIS
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with my Fear makes them sloppy. bomb maker, it was your --

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: We've found three more names for you,

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Three? Avner seems dismayed, as if someone’s just put a heavy we on his back.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Yes, three. Thought you’d be pleased.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I am. Who?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Kemal Nasser, Kemal Adwan and Yussuf Najjer.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: That's -- Adwan and Abu Yussuf? Where?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Lebanon. They’re in Beirut.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Beirut. ; Nasser, Adwan and Najjer.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Serious characters.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Extremely serious. Ayner thinks. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Smile, Monsieur Storsch. A second Christmas!

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I'd like to pay you a little extra for this, for these three names. Six hundred thousand. Dollars.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Monsieur Storsch, my group, we don't care much for governments. Any governments. We don't work with or for them. That's an absolute condition of... My theory. You understand? They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I learned that your sudden generosity was an attempt to buy our acquiescence in your sharing my information with, let us say... CIA or MI6é or, or Mossad, even.  128 129

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I don't work for --

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Oh you have no idea who you work for, trust me, you don’t. Lie to me and you will find me abruptly unreachable. And unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Let me buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You save your money. At these prices, you're going to need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ephraim, still in his coat, is standing amidst the team, which is busy, everyone working like clockwork preparing dinner. Avner is in the kitchen, assisted by Hans, simmer a gravy, making spaetzle over a boiling pot, chopping dil Steve and Robert are setting the table, while Carl select and pours wine like a sommelier. ,They’re.now a family, domesticated, concentrated, everyone knows what Avner exp of them. Ephraim watches, awkward, out of place, intrigue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The team is digging in: sliced lamb, a big bowl of boiled potatoes, mint jelly, noodle soup, rolls, wine etc.. Ephr has the place of honor and his coat’s off now, but he sti looks uncomfortable and out of place, picking at the food Next to Robert, sitting incongruously on the table, is a little crane, exquisitely detailed, with a claw hammer dangling from it. Ephraim glances at it from time to time everyone else ignores it, used to it.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: It's obviously significant information.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Abu Yussef! He’s like number three in the whole Palestinian network, it’s like Arafat, Habash and him! O£ course he’s significant, he’s the brains of the fedayeen!  80.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: {overlapping Steve above:) Thanks for the instruction. And the enthusiasm. I know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Next to Salalmeh, Abu Yussuf’s the worst guy we’re after, right? And, and Adwan plans all the actions in the West Bank, right? We get the significance! These are serious targets! We want to go to Beirut.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: No. You keep out of the Arab countries. Mossad and the army will take care of it.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: So much for no dead civilians.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: {To Carl, grim:) You need to control yourself. vee (to Robert, irritated:) What is that, that contraption?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Oh: It’s just a ~-

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You can’t send the army. We can’t allow that.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: You can't allow it?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Our source doesn’t know we're Mossad.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: You aren’t Mossad. Robert turns a tiny crank. The crane wheels around to the Gish with he boiled potatoes. Robert turns another crank the crane’s claw drops inte the bowl, opening as it desce Another crank and the claw clamps around a potato. Robert turns cranks and pulls levers until the little crane has dropped the potato onto his plate. Ephraim stares at this incredulous. Then he decides to pretend it didn’t happen.  Bl.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: If commandos go to Beirut, our source will cut us off.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Why don’t you and I go for a walk and talk about this? Alone.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: The food will get cold.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER STEVE
dialogues.text: (Over Hans: ) (Over Hans:) We have to go to Beirut. Three names! We're good at It’s our information. It's this! We deserve this our job. chance!

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: That's touching. In a juvenile sort of way. Listen, you've done reasonably well.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: “Reasonably”?!

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: You’re spending a lot of money. Well, we expected that. The world’s already forgetting Munich.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The world forgot before the athletes were in their graves.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: People are going to find it difficult, connecting these bodies with the crimes they committed. This is... unimaginably risky for us. You understand that, yes? For our country. Me being here with you, now, is risky. An operation like Beirut could become a big problem.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Let us do it and it won’t be a problem. ee OF  82.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Look, lots of people in Mossad don’t know about you. No one knows. Everyone's asking “Who's killing the fedayeen? Is it our guys? Why weren't we told?” Big egos, lots of screaming. Maybe I can include... one or two of you, but excluding Mossad, or the army, is impossible. Accept it.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: We will, but our source won't.

dialogues.speaker: EPBRAIM
dialogues.text: Who‘s your source? Carl and Avner look at one another. Carl smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Avner:)} It’s time you told me. And that, by the way, is not a request, it's an order.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: You can't order him, he doesn't work for you.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: (to Carl:} Shut up. (to Avner:) I pay you, you work for me.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I work for a metal box in a bank in Geneva. The box pays me.

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: You want it to find it empty?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I want you to let us do our work.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: You should be pleased, look how eager we've gotten!

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Some of us were always eager.  83.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: We’ve reached consensus that this was a necessary thing to do, even if it stretches the definition of our mission a bit.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: We want to do what we‘ve promised to do, what we promised you and Israel and our source. While everyone's talking, Robert repeats the potato lift his crane. He drops the potato this time in Ephraim’s pla Ephraim looks at the potato and then slams his hand down, hard, on the table!

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: {losing it, screaming:

dialogues.speaker: WHAT IS THE MATTER WITH YOU
dialogues.text: ALL OF YOU? GROW UP AND bo IT

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: I hope the old lady upstairs enjoyed that. She's a little deaf but I doubt she had any trouble hearing you.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I think she's Leni Reifenstahl. The lady upst~-

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: She's not Leni Reifenstahl. (to Ephraim: ) He's not kidding, he thinks she's --

dialogues.speaker: EPHRAIM
dialogues.text: Give me the source and we’ll let you take part.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Let us go to Beirut and use our source and find the rest of the targets. Let us do our job.  130 131 B4.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: If she turns out te be Leni Reifenstahl can we kill her? Ephraim looks around the table, furious. Without a word h stands, grabs his hat and coat and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Oh well. It was a good career.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I think our careers ended when we accepted this job. Don’t you think? You heard him: No one knows we're here. No one will ever want to know. I think my life ended when I took this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four Zodiac rafts are nearing the shore. Twenty Sayeret Matkal commandos are in the boat; some are in wetsuits, s are dressed as tourists, male and female. The boats pull on beach. The commandos disembark. Sealed bags are opened containing shoes, pistols, grenades, knives and uzis. They move to the waiting cars and pile in. In the near @istance there’s an outdoor restaurant, with a bandstand. People are dancing and the band is playing top 40s hits, in Arabic. The cars drive out onto the main drag of the A Riviera: pre-1980s Beirut, beautiful hotels, casinos, electric lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert drives, Avner beside him. In the seat behind them, four Commandos, silent, huge, squeezed in uncomfortably. Another commando in the back is preparing Uzis. One of th commandos, disguised as a woman, early 30s, is stuffing h grenades into his bra. This is Ehud Barak, the squad lead

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE COMMANDOS
dialogues.text: Ow, Ehud, you don’t make a pretty woman.

dialogues.speaker: BARAK
dialogues.text: But I feel pretty, that's what matters. (to Avner, holding out his hand: ) Ehud Barak.  132 133 85. Avner reaches back, shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Um, Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: BARAK
dialogues.text: Daniel what? Avner smiles and shrugs. Barak looks at his men; they're confused and suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You brought a lot of guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other rental cars and the truck are waiting, with the xest of the commandos, the old man and woman from the tru the other drivers -- all Mossad agents -~ and Steve. The Plymouth station wagon and two other cars pull up behind apartment building. The commandos pile out. The Plymouth's tailgate is opened and the Uzis are handed out. Steve goes to Avner and Robert...

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: A lot of guns, huh? To shoot three guys. Avner nods, worried.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, THE COURTYARD OF AN APARTMENT BUILDING, BEIRUT
dialogues.text: Five Palestinian men, armed with old rifles and AK-47s, a smoking, talking, standing guard. The commandos in drag enter the courtyard. One of the Palestinians walks toward them. The commandos draw silenced Berettas and shoot; the Palestinians are shot before they can lift their guns. Th commandos use knives to make sure all five are dead. Behi them, commandos in uniform, some with stockings pulled ov their faces, rush silently in, Avner, Robert and Steve am them. Robert hesitates to watch the commandos dressed as women finishing their grisly work.

dialogues.speaker: BEIRUT
dialogues.text: An explosion, blowing the door off Abu Yussuf's apartment  ra we Oo 136 137 138 86.

dialogues.speaker: BEIRUT
dialogues.text: Another explosion blows the door of Kemal Nasser's apartm straight into his room.

dialogues.speaker: BEIRUT
dialogues.text: A group of commandos bursts round the corner, unexpectedl encountering twenty armed Palestinian men. The commandos immediately open fire with Ugis. The Palestinians are scrambling over one another, shouting, trying to take aim blown to pieces by machine gun fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandos enter Nasser’s apartment through the smoke. The room, apparently unoccupied, has been shattered by the bl that blew the front door into the room. The door has stru and is covering what’s left of a table. Dozens of pages o paper, covered with text, thrown into the air by the blas are fluttering down. Some of the pages are on fire. An intelligence agent among the commandos is rushing about, grabbing up the pages, blowing out flames and stuffing al printed matter he can find into a satchel. The commandos use flashlights to look through the smoke a around the room, trying to find Nasser.

dialogues.speaker: A COMMANDO
dialogues.text: Where the fuck is he? One of the commandos, standing by the front door, which i now smashed up against the table, signals for the others stop looking. Gun at the ready, the commando flips the fr door over with his foot. Nasser, in his thirties, a bloody mess, is barely conscio crushed under the door. The commandos look at him for a moment. The one who’s found Nasser gives a nod and then h starts firing into Nasser’s body; the other commandos fol suit. Nasser’s body jerks and dances as it’s struck by bullets. Then the shooting stops. The commando uses his f and slides the door over the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 139 140 141 87. Adwan, coughing and blind from the smoke, is rising from sleep in his bed, the television on, what's left of his d swinging from its hinges. Commandos are entering his room He gropes for his Kalashnikov, screaming with rage as the commandos fire, their magnesium bullets driving him down to the bed. He fires off a round of bullets in the genera direction of his attackers, wounding one commando, perhap severely -- his fire provoking a dramatic increase in ret fire. Adwan's body is shredded by the bullets. The mattre he’s lying on bursts into flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abu Yussuf is trying to rise, wounded by bullets and from shrapnel from the bomb that tore off his door. His wife a his teenaged son, holding a metal tube from a vaccuum cleaner, are standing in an inner doorway, screaming. Two commandos and Avner have entered the room, and the comman are raising their guns, aiming at the wounded man. Yussuf wife throws herself in front of her husband just as the commandos fire.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (to the commandos: )'-

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: But it’s too fast, too late and the gunfire kills the wom and her husband. Her bloody body topples onto his. The boy raises the vacuum cleaner tube, growling, shaking crying. All the guns in the room swing in his direction. boy drops the tube, sinks to his knees and raises his arm surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a gruesome mess, smoky air, shouting, and bodies scattered on the ground. Commandos rush out of the buildi

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Avner and Robert emerge from the courtyard of the buildin into gunfire. In the apartment building across the street another firefight is in full force -- automatic weapon fi smoke pouring from a few windows, bodies of Palestinians lying on the sidewalk in pools of blood. Avner and Robert duck behind a bullet-riddled dumpster. A couple of Israel commandos are there already, strafing the upper windows o the building with machine gun fire to provide cover for t commandos who are running out the front door.  142 143 88. A Sayeret Maktal Commando gives a signal with his right h and the other commandos, and Robert and Avner, head for t getaway rental cars. Other cars, burning, flipped on thei sides, block the street. A narrow escapeway through the wreckage remains. The cars speed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner is sitting at a table, waiting for Louis, exhausted nervous. He's been reading several French newspapers. He checks his watch. He’s been waiting a long time. A big car pulls up, idling. The rear window rolls down. Louis is inside. Avner stays at the table. Louis stays in the car.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: My papa would like to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Who? .

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: My papa. He runs our little group.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I thought you ran the group.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Everybody works for someone. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I wasn’t in Beirut.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Someone was there. The Israeli army, according to every newspaper on earth. (beat) But you stayed away. After you paid so extravagantly for the information. Louis opens the door and slides over, making room for Avn

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: I don’t like to keep my papa waiting.  145 eo.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I need to tell my people where I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: You don't know where you're going. You'll need to wear this. Louis takes a black sleep mask out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Go to hell, Louis, I'm not -- Louis slams the door shut.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: {to the man behind him:) We're done here. The car starts to pull away from the curb. Avner stands u

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Come on, Louis, it's crazy, you don't expect me to -- The car starts to drive away. Avner has to chase it a distance down the street. He catches up with it and slams his hand on the back of the car; it stops and the rear do opens again. Avner hesitates, then gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis holds out the mask. Avner takes it.

dialogues.speaker: LOULS
dialogues.text: If you feel carsick, I brought candied ginger.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I have a strong stomach. Avner puts on the mask. Blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner’s mask is roughly removed. A group of young childre are standing around the car door, looking in at him. One the kids is holding his mask. As Avner, blinking, gets ou of the car, the kids run off, chattering and giggling.  146 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very old stone barn, main house, sheds, a sheepfold, a stable, ringed by spectacular mountains. Geese and a dogs patrol the yard. The light is gorgeous, golden. Avner walks towards the farmhouse and the sound of conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner comes through the front door into a large common room/kitchen -- a room from the Middle Ages but with mode amenities, including in one corner a large commercial sto The room is full of adults and many children. Some of the adults look like working farmers, some like small-time business people. The driver of Avner's car and the large are drinking wine. Louis is in a corner, talking to a wom his sister Sylvie. Avner starts towards Louis when his sleeve is tugged. He looks down. An old man in a battered cap and coat, sitting on a stool, points towards the kitc area. At a counter near the stove, Louis's Papa, in his vigorou 60s, is chopping vegetables. He glances up, gives Avner a quick appraising glance,waves him over and continues with cooking.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: Louis says you’re a cook.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I... I know how to cook.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: You'll help me. You bring these... He hands Avner a big metal bowl filled with kidneys. He points to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There. Avner brings the bowl to the sink, turns on the tap. Papa hurries over, nudges Avner out of the way, turns off the He gestures with the large knife he’s holding.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No! Don't wash! It will taste like boiled sponge.  148 149 91.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Then why put them in the sink?

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: If the juices spurt out, it’s big mess, the whole kitchen smells like piss. Peel off the fat. He dexterously peels off a kidney's thin membrane of fat.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me see your hands. Avner shows Papa his hands.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Too big for a good cook! That was my problem too. Papa holds his right hand up, flat against Avner's.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘d have been a master but I have thick stupid butcher's hands, like yours. We are tragic men. Butcher's hands, gentle souls. He tousles Avner's hair, gently, affectionately slaps his face. Across the room, Louis is watching their exchange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, drinking wine, is staring with an uncharacteristic sullenness out a window. He's watching Avner and Papa walking together towards an orchard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papa is picking green plums off a tree, tossing them into big basket Avner is holding.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: These are going to be too sour to eat.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: Skin them and prick them and boil them in sugar, bake them in honey and dough. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAPA (cont'd) A little torture, you'll see how nice they are. You call me papa.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I have a papa already. Papa stops picking and looks at Avner.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: And you are devoted to him.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Am I here because of what happened in Beirut?

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: Your papa must be proud of his son. We'll pick a few, let the rest ripen. There are too many.people “to feed. But -~

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You have to feed your family.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: (grinning: ) Yes! We don’t work with governments.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Louis said, but -~

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: But you did what you had to, because you have to feed your family. They turn to go back to the farmhouse. Louis is in the window. Papa and Avner stare at him; Avne waves. Louis raises his glass in salute. 150 INT. THE COMMON ROOM OF THE FARMHOUSE ~ DAY i590 The whole group is seated around the massive table. Food wine are being served by the women.  93. Papa is at the head of the table, Avner seated on his rig e@ Louis and Sylvie sit a few seats down.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: (to Avner:) I blew up trains, bridges, trucks full of Germans during the war. My brothers died. My papa and my sister were both hanged, she was a young girl.

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIE
dialogues.text: Papa, the guest doesn’t want to hear your war stories.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: (ignoring her:) We paid this price so Vichy scum could be replaced by Gaullist scum and the Nazis could be replaced by Stalin and America. We stay away from government. (to the table, crossing himself: ) We say grace. e The others start to cross themselves and pray.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Maybe our guest could lead us. Papa looks at Avner. Avner starts to cross himself. Papa grabs his hand, stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: It’s not required. (to Louis, angry) You lead us instead. Louis deliberately crosses himself backwards. LouIS Our Father, who gives us obedient, respectful clients who obey the rules according to which our business thrives -~ Over this, one of the older woman raps her knuckles on th table.  151 4.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS OLDER WOMAN, (FRENCH)
dialogues.text: And punish those who (to Papa) . transgress against us, whose I won't have my grandchildre prevarications and deceptions listen to his blasphemous -

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (FRENCH)
dialogues.text: (to Louis, angry!) It's not all for business! I didn't do ali this for the fucking money!

dialogues.speaker: SYLVIE, (FRENCH)
dialogues.text: Why'd you do it then? You've made millions from this.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: (to Avner:) In my despair I fathered madmen who dress like factory workers but never do manual labor, who read nonsense and spout pompous bullshit about Algerians and, and who love nothing, not Algerians or French or flesh and blood or anything living. (to Louis, pointedly:) So I have sympathy for a man who can say "I have a papa." Who does what he must for his family. {to Sylvie, in FRENCH:) I did it for my family, for you. You... centaur! You minotaur! Syivie laughs at this.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: I will say grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, the large man and the driver are waiting by the ca Papa and Avner stand apart. A small child is hanging on t Avner's hand, swinging. Papa holds a wax paper parcel tie neatly with green gardener’s twine.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: In the resistance there were occasionally some of your uncles, your cousins.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: Ruben, Benjamin and Moshe.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: oh.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: When it came to killing Germans, even we didn't have such a fierce appetite for it. (beat) There's some opinion that you should be punished for what happened in Beirut.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: We didn't know so many would die.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: I'm in business with death. Do you think I'm squeamish? Papa pats Avner's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The world has been rough with you, with your tribe, your family. It’s right to respond roughly to such treatment - Papa puts his arm across Avner's shoulder and walks him towards the car. When Louis is within earshot:

dialogues.speaker: PAPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You pay well and you pay promptly, so we'll continue together, but no more infractions.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: You remind me of myself at your age. Louis hands Avner the mask and gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (to Papa: ) Thank you. You have my word. Avner gets into the car, closes the door. Papa raps on th glass. The window rolls down, and Papa leans in to Avner. hands Avner the parcel:  152 153 96.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: A few andouvillettes and some boudin noir, black blood sausage, and a Loire cheese, Selles sur Cher, they cover it in ash to preserve it.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: You could have been my son. Louis winces slightly. Avner’s embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: PAPA
dialogues.text: But you're not. Remember that. We'll do business. But you aren't family. Papa walks away. ‘The car drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence, Avner is blindfolded. He starts to lift the mask Louis reaches over and roughly pushes it back in place. INT. LOUIS’S CAR, ARRIVING NEAR THE KITCHEN DESIGN SHOP,

dialogues.speaker: PARIS
dialogues.text: The car pulls up to a halt, curbside. Avner removes the mask. Louis is thinking. Silence. Avner doesn’t know whether to stay in the car or leave. He puts his hand on the door handle. LOurs I have a new name for you.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I want Salameh.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You know where he is. You know where all the names are. Salameh. Lours Untouchable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of hearing that. You’re wasting my time. Avner starts to get out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Zaid Muchassi. Avner doesn’t recognize the name and doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Zaid Muchassi. He’s in Athens in two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Not one of cur names.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Nevertheless. He's Black September's KGB contact.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Hussein al-Chir was the KGB contact.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: But you put a bomb under Monsieur al-Chir’s bed in Cyprus, and now he’s defunct. Muchassi is his replacement. I hear he’s much tougher than his predecessor. Avner doesn’t respond.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We offer Muchassi‘s whereabouts at the new rate.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: The new rate.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Three names for six hundred thousand is $200,000 for one name. Avner nods.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I’1ll need you to get me a place to work in Athens.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Of course... A safe house.  154 155 156 98. OMITTED ° 154

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner, Steve and Robert, carrying a duffel bag and a smal suitcase, are standing in front of a derelict building, t crummiest on a block of really crummy warehouses; they‘re looking in disbelief at the address.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Louis's idea of a joke?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I've had nightmares that look like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large and utterly derelict apartment. It's unfinished a abandoned. Cinderblock walls, cement floor, dank. It's unfurnished, except for a small transistor radio, a few rickety chairs, a couple of crates and two stacks of old mattresses -- a pile of five, and a pile of four ~~ each tied with hemp. Carl counts the mattresses, while Hans is putting cartons of take-out food on one of the crates. Robert is sitting on the floor, carefully wiring together four squat, dinged-up, rust-spotted cylinders, hooking th up to a remote-controlled fuse, and then placing the contraption into a small suitcase, surrounding each devic with newspaper to prevent jostling. Four more of the cylinders, more decrepit than the ones Robert's working o sit nearby on the floor. Steve and Avner watch him.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: (talking while he works) When they explode they’1l toss little white balls of phosphorus around his room. Each ball is like a little sun. It burns at around 5,000 degrees. The air catches fire, everything melts. The bad news is they're grenades. I’m altering them to use with a remote detonator. And also I should mention they're quite old, only four looked viable. We'll have to dump the rest. Robert puts the unusable four grenades in a canvas duffel  157

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: There's a porter at the hotel where Muchassi is staying. He‘ll let us in the room when Muchassi‘s out.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Who provided these grenades?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Louis.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thank him for that. INT. THE SAFE HOUSE, ATHENS - LATE NIGHT i57 Food containers are strewn about. Carl, Hans and Avner ar fast asleep. Robert squeezes Avner's hand, gently. Avner opens his eyes. Robert makes a sign: Quiet. Steve is awak gun drawn. The door is opening. Avner draws his ‘22, and he and Steve move to either side the door. Robert picks up the suitcase and the duffel bag and steps behind Avner. Four Palestinian men come into the room: one about fifty, in their thirties, one of whom is the leader, named Ali, one in his early twenties. One of the older men is carryi groceries. Ali flips the light switch. The Palestinian carrying the groceries drops them as he and his comrades draw their guns.

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (ARABIC)
dialogues.text: I have this house from the French, I have permission, I am with Fatah! PLO! PLO! It's been arranged, don't shoot or we'll kill you, don't -- we have a right to be here, we paid.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (over this, in pidgin ARABIC and GERMAN: ) Put your guns away! Do it, now, we'll shoot, we're... We paid too, we paid too, Red Army Faction! Red Army Faction!

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: ETA! ETA! Basque, Basque!  100.

dialogues.speaker: OK. OK. OK. OK.
dialogues.text: They're all pointing their guns. Avner glances at Carl, t then lowers his gun slowly. The leader of the Palestinian group follows suit. Carl, Hans and Robert lower their gun next, as do two more Palestinians. Steve and the youngest Palestinian continue to hold their guns out, a tense face off.

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (ARABIC)
dialogues.text: Said, put it down, now.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (in GERMAN, to Steve:) Jurgen! You also! Said lowers his gun, as does Steve, after a quick bemused glance at Avner. Everyone's got a finger on a trigger, scared.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who told you to come here?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: The man at the bar on Hadjidakis Street, the man who works for the French. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: What French? Louis? The Palestinian leader shrugs, not recognizing the name.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE OLDER PALESTINIANS
dialogues.text: Who are you? English?

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I'm ETA. (pointing to Carl and Hans) They're Red Army Faction. (pointing to Steve:) He’s ANC, Jurgen. Afrikaans. (pointing to Avner:) Bruno. He's from Hamburg.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: We're from Amman. I'm Ali. (pointing at the others:} Said, George, Abed.  158 101. Everyone nods in tense greeting.

dialogues.speaker: ALI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We paid for two nights, he said it was safe.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: He told us the same.

dialogues.speaker: ONE OF THE OLDER PALESTINIANS
dialogues.text: Yes. Safe house.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: So. So is it... So we're safe?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Safe. Everyone is safe.

dialogues.speaker: INT, THE SAFE HOUSE, ATHENS
dialogues.text: Carl, Hans and Robert are sleeping, Robert curled around suitcase, his head on the duffel bag. Steve is sitting on mattress, gun still in his hand. The twenty-year-old Palestinian is leaning against a wall, also keeping watch Two other Palestinians are asleep. The remnants of their dinner are mingled with the Israelis’ take-out. Avner and Ali are talking quietly. The twenty-year old Palestinian goes to the radio, crouch turns it on, fidgets with the dial till he finds a statio playing Indian music, a woman singing in a high nasal voi Satisfied, he resumes his post, staring at Steve. Steve stands, goes to the radio, crouches, turns the dial Greek taverna music. The Palestinian returns, crouches besides Steve, turns the dial back to the Indian station, then, looking up at Steve for an instant, continues to mo the dial till he finds an English-language station, stopp when he hears the opening notes of The Staple Singers’ “I know a place.” With a terse nod of agreement, Steve gets goes to the mattress, sits, and the Palestinian goes back his post. Avner and Ali are talking while the radio plays behind th  102.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Eventually the Arab states will rise against Israel -- they don't like Palestinians, but they hate the Jews more. It won‘t be like 1967, the rest of the world will see by then what the Israelis do to us, and they won’t help when Egypt and Syria attack. Even Jordan. Israel will cease to exist. Avner doesn't respond. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: I guess. Only...

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: This is a dream. You can't take back a country you never had.

dialogues.speaker: ALT
dialogues.text: You sound like a Jew.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (smiling: ) Fuck you. I'm the voice inside your head, telling you what you know is true. Your people have nothing to bargain with. You'll never get the land back. You'll all die, old men in refugee camps, waiting for “Palestine.”

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (a shrug, easy:) We have a lot of children, they'll have children, so we can wait forever, and, and... if we need to, we can make the whole planet unsafe for Jews.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You kill Jews, and the world feels bad for them, and thinks you're animals.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Yeah, but then the world will see how they've made us into animals. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALI (cont'd) They'll start to ask questions about the conditions in our cages.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You're Arabs. There are lots of places for Arabs.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: You’re a Jew sympathizer. All you Germans are soft on Israel, you give us money but you feel guilty about Hitler, and the Jews exploit your guilt. My father didn't gas any Jews.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Ali.

dialogues.speaker: ALT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: You really miss your father's olive trees? The crappy’ village he came from? You honestly think you have to get back all that... nothing, chalky soil and stone huts? That's what you want for your kids? Ali looks into Avner's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALT
dialogues.text: It is. It absolutely is. It'll take a hundred years, but we'll win. How long did it take the Jews to get their own country? How long did it take the Germans to make Germany?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: And look how well that worked cut.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: You don't know what it is not to have a home. That’s why you European reds don‘t get it. You say it‘s nothing, but you have a home to come back to. ETA, ANC, IRA, PLO -- we all pretend we care about your “International revolution.“ But we don’t care. We want to be nations. Home is everything.  159 160 i61 162 163 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans and Robert, carrying a suitcase, watch a porter unio the door to a room. Robert, then Hans step inside. The porter tries to follow them in. Hans blocks the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: {to Porter:) You go downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: No, I watch. Hans hands him a few more bills. The porter smilingly accepts the money, but still he tries to see into the roo

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You only take money in closet and papers, yes?

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Yes. Robert pushes past Hans, leaving the room.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Let's go. EXT. DOWN THE STREET FROM THE HOTEL ARISTIDES — NIGHT 162 Two cars pulls up, about a hundred yards down the street the hotel. Steve gets out of one of them. He looks both ways. The street is empty. He takes out a pistol with a silencer and shoots out the street light nearest the car. Steve gets back into the car, driver's side, Hans in the passenger seat, Carl in the back with the duffel bag. They wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert and Avner are inside, Avner at the wheel. They're waiting. They're not speaking.  164 165 166 105.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans sees a black Mercedes coming down the street.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Look. The black Mercedes arrives at the hotel. Two Russians in suits get out.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: The Russians arrive in their pumpkin coach, and... A Palestinian man, Zaid Muchassi, comes out of the black Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cinderella.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner and Robert watch, slouched down, as Ali and another Palestinian from the safe house get out of the black Mercedes. Muchassi enters the hotel with the other Palestinians. The Russians stay outside.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Do we detonate if the other Arabs go into the room with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans, Carl and Steve are watching the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: What are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Wait for the signal.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Why are the Russians waiting? Why don't they leave?

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: They're waiting. We're waiting. Stay calm.  167 168 106.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: I'm calm. Tell the goddam Russians to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner and Robert watch the Russians, lounging near the ca chatting and smoking. The wait is agonizing. Finally a porter comes out the front door of the hotel. H lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: He's in his room. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Is he alone? How do we know he ~-

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: DO IT! pO IT! FLIP THE SWITCH! Robert flicks the switch. Nothing. Robert flicks the swit rapidly back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Shit. Stupid shit piece of ~-

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: What?! What?! Oh fuck not again, not --~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're waiting for the blast.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Where‘s the explosion, it should have exploded by now, what's -~

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Another malfunction. Did the -- Maybe it’s delayed, or, or --

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: He screwed up again. What do we do? Hans reaches over to the back seat, grabs the duffel bag.  169 170 i7k 107.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Careful with that stuff! What are you -- Hans gets out of the car with the duffel bag. He walks briskly but calmly towards the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert is pressing the remote. Avner grabs it from him an tries flicking the switch himself.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: It has to work, it has to, what’s the matter with it, can’t you make it -

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: We’ll have to go back and retrieve the explosives, I’m sorry, I, I don’t -- Robert spots Hans heading across the street towards the hotel. .

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Wait here. Avner gets out of the car, crosses the street, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: «+. moves towards the hotel. Hans, nodding to the KGB men, goes in to the hotel. The porter sees Hans and, surprised, goes in after him. Avner is nearing the front door, but he stops when he see Ali and the other Palestinian emerge from inside. Avner ducks into a doorway so that Ali doesn't see him. The Palestinians confer with the KGB agents. Avner doesn't kn what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans is rushing up the stairs, the porter in pursuit.  172 173 108.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey mister! What are you doing? What are you doing in here? Hans, as he goes up the stairs, hangs the duffel bag on h left arm, unzips it and takes out a grenade, transfers th grenade to his left hand, and with his right hand takes o his gun. The porter, right behind him, freezes when he sees the grenade. They're both panting with exertion.

dialogues.speaker: LATE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Hans, breathing heavily, stops outside Muchassi's door. t porter arrives behind him, keeping his distance. Hans, grenade in his left hand, gun in his right, shoots lock and kicks the door open. Then, clumsily, he pulls th grenade pin with his right hand, in which he still holds gun. He tosses. the grenade into the room, past Muchassi, is scrambling to pull his gun from his coat. When Muchass sees the grenade he forgets about the gun and rushes towa the door. Hans swings the duffel bag with his left arm, clouting Muchassi in the face, knocking him back into the room. Hans throws the bag into the room, pulls the door shut, then, dropping his gun, he hangs on with both hands the knob as Muchassi, inside, tries frantically to pull t door open, yelling in Arabic. There is a flash and the door tears off its hinges, blowi into Hans, pushing him with a THUD into the hallway wall opposite. Smoke rolls out of the open door. Hans throws t door off and staggers past the porter, who is pressed aga a wall, terrified. Hans gropes in the wreckage for his gu finds it, and stumbles down the stairs. A second, much larger explosion: the other bombs in the room detonate. H and the porter fall. Hans gets up and runs down the stair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KGB agents and the two Palestinians look up as the gl in Muchassi's room's windows blow out, Little balls of phosporus sailing outward into the night air. Ali and the other Palestinian, guns drawn, start back int the hotel,just as Hans is running out. Hans fires his gun the black Mercedes’s window, shattering it, forcing the Palestinians and the Russians to dive for cover.  174 1038. The porter appears at the door of the hotel, shouting.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE
dialogues.text: He runs after Hans, who is running across the street towa his car. One of the Russians takes aim at Hans. Avner, fr the doorway, shoots the KGB agent in the back; he falls, screaming. Hans and the porter duck in the middle of the street. Han grabs the porter by his collar and drags him towards his Back at the black Mercedes, Ali turns in the direction of shot. He sees Avner. Ali fires, misses, forcing Avner to to another doorway. Then Ali falls, hit by a bullet fired Carl, who is standing across the street. Robert, standing next to Carl, also fires. Ignoring the bullets, the Palestinian in his 30s heads for Ali in the street. Hans has reached the car. He shoves the porter in the bac seat and dives in after him. Steve reverses the car and lurches into the street. Robert and Carl run, crouching, scramble in to Steve's car, Robert in the back, Carl up front, as the other KGB agent starts firing. Bullets stri the car. The car door is open for Avner. The Palestinian in his 30s is bending over Ali. He props up, trying to see how badly he’s hurt. Ali searches the doorways across the street till he finds Avner. They make eye contact for a moment just before the car screeches up blocking the two men from one another’s sight. The car drives off; the doorway is empty. As the car drives away, the other two Palestinians run to Ali.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is tearing through the city. Robert and Hans try unsuccessfully to subdue the cursing, struggling porter. Steve, driving, holds up his .22 and fires a shot through roof of the car. The porter stops struggling, but he’s erying and cursing Hans.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (GREEK)
dialogues.text: You lied to me and you (to Robert: } tricked me, you're going to This is thanks to you, are hell, you murderer, you you incapable of making bloody monster! something that works?  175

dialogues.speaker: PORTER, (GREEK)
dialogues.text: He opened the door of the room, shot of the lock and just threw a bomb right at that poor man! Oh my God, oh my God, that poor man, he tried to escape, you wouldn't let him he held the door and purned that poor man to death. Oh my God, ch my God...

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: (over the porter, to Hans: ) You don’t need Greek to know what he’s saying, do you? Just shut this crazy asshole up? Did we kill that, that Arab guy, and the KGB, did we

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: {to Robert) | Where did you gét your training?! Every fucking bomb, every one has gone wrong, it's lucky you haven't blown yourself to kingdom come!

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: (to the Porter:) * Quiet! Be quiet! Shut up! * Does anyone speak Greek? * What's he saying? *

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Did we kill a Russian? That's -- Oh God, did we kill @-- that's not good, that’s -

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: {over Steve: } Did you get the detonator!? We left the car, we didn't check for prints and we ~- It isn't my fault if... I wasn't trained to do this!

dialogues.speaker: THEM
dialogues.text: The yelling stops. Hans stares at Robert, The porter is now moaning to through the rear-view mirror. himself, softly.

dialogues.speaker: STEVE
dialogues.text: Holy shit. as does Steve

dialogues.speaker: OF ATHENS
dialogues.text: Avner and Hans are eitting on the hood of the getaway car Steve is pacing and Cari is inspecting the car's interior Making sure no evidence is left. Robert is sithing on a cinderblock. fhe porter, sunk in deep dejection, is still sitting in the back of the car. A new car is parked nearb  lil.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Shin Beit wanted bomb dismantiers, they pulled me from the army, a toymaker, they figured I’m good with small machines. After Munich, they asked if I could build bombs instead.

dialogues.speaker: HANS
dialogues.text: Give me some money. Everyone hands him bills, till he has a large pile. He go to the porter and offers him the stack of bills.

dialogues.speaker: HANS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Hans flings the money in the porter's lap. The porter spi in disgust and throws it back at Hans. The team gets in the third car and drives away. The porter watches them drive away. He looks at the money the pavement, spits on it again, and walks away, leaving to blow down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avner and Louis in a dim, mostly empty coffee house. Political posters on the wall protesting the war in Vietn the Algerian conflict, an ugly caricature of Nixon and DeGaulle. Louis is rather ostentatiously counting America money from an envelope Avner’s handed him; this makes Avn nervous. small black-and-white television is playing on t bar, volume low.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Salameh is in London. He goes there periodically to meet with his CIA contact --

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: His what?!

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Salameh works for the CIA.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Bulishit.  188 112.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: Salameh guarantees that Black September won’t touch American diplomats, In exchange the CIA gives him lots of money. They don’t ask what he uses it for.

dialogues.speaker: AVNER
dialogues.text: Did he tell them about Munich? In advance? Did the CIA know about Munich?

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: The CIA didn't even know Black September existed before Munich! Since then he’s been busy, hasn’t he? Louis nods towards the TV.

dialogues.speaker: LOUIS
dialogues.text: All manner of costly exercises. cuT TO TV

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN
dialogues.text: Footage of the Athens airport shooting: the shattered air lounge, bodies on the ground, people wandering, dazed and bleeding; seriously injured people in hospital beds.

dialogues.speaker: LOUTS
